Attorney‐General's Department

PROPOSED PART XA OF THE INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS ACT 1988—VALIDITY OF UNION REPRESENTATION AND MEMBERSHIP PROVISIONS IN AWARDS AND CERTIFIED AGREEMENTS

I refer to your letter dated 13 August 1996 seeking advice about the validity of provisions included in awards and certified agreements and which are concerned with union representation and membership. The background to this matter, your questions and my answers to them are set out below.
BACKGROUND

2. The Senate Economics References Committee, which has been conducting an inquiry into the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 (the Bill), has sought the views of the Department of Industrial Relations (the Department) about the validity of provisions concerning union representation and membership which are included in awards and certified agreements. The Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association (SDA) has submitted to the Committee that proposed Part XA of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 (the Act), which is set out in Schedule 16 to the Bill, will, once it is enacted, preclude provisions of that kind.
3. The SDA has given the following clauses as examples of those which have for many years been included in consent awards and certified agreements to which it is a party.

`1. For the duration of this Award/Agreement the company recognises the SDA as being the Union that shall have exclusive representation of the employees who are covered by this Award. This exclusive representation will extend to all terms and conditions of employment, whether those terms and conditions are subject to this Award/Agreement or not.

2. It is the policy of the company that all its employees subject to the Award/Agreement will be encouraged to join the SDA. Accordingly, the company undertakes to positively promote union membership at the point of recruitment by strongly recommending that all employees join the SDA.
3. All new employees will be given an application form to join the SDA at the point of engagement together with a statement of the company's policy.
4. All employees not currently members of the SDA will be given an application form to join the SDA together with a statement of the company's policy.

5. The company undertakes upon authorisation to deduct union membership dues, as levied by the Union in accordance with its rules, from the pay of employees who are members of the Union. Such monies collected will be forwarded to the Union at the beginning of each month together with all necessary information to enable the reconciliation and crediting of subscriptions to members' accounts.'
QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS
QUESTION 1

Your Department's view is that cll. 1 and 5 are not presently enforceable under the Act, and would remain unenforceable after the enactment of the Bill. The department's particular views are as follows.
. Clause 1 purports to provide for `exclusive representation'. This is beyond the capacity of the parties to establish by agreement.

. Clause 5 deals with subject matter which is beyond the scope of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission's (the Commission's) existing award‐making power and all five clauses would be beyond the scope of the Commission's award making power under the Act as amended by the Bill.
. Clauses 2 to 4 appear to be no more than statements of policy.
You ask whether these views are correct?
SHORT ANSWER

4. In my view, cll. 1 and 5 are not enforceable under the Act. However, I think cll. 2, 3 and 4 are more than statements of policy and could, at least in theory, be the subject of enforcement action under the Act. I agree that none of the clauses would be enforceable under the Act if it were amended by the Bill.
REASONS

5. Clause 1 is not a matter which, under the present Act, two parties can establish conclusively by agreement. That is because the Commission has the power to make an inconsistent award or order in relation to any demarcation dispute which results from a union's attempt to procure exclusive representation rights (see the definitions of `industrial dispute' and `demarcation dispute' in s.4(1)of the Act and social security.111(1)(b) and (f) of the Act). In that sense, the SDA has no conclusive right to exclusively represent employees which could be enforced under the Act.

6. A dispute about the deduction of union dues cannot be an industrial dispute for the purposes of the Act (see R v Portus; Ex parte ANZ Banking Group Ltd (1972) 127 CLR 353; and Re Alcan Australia Ltd; Ex parte Federation of Industrial, Manufacturing and Engineering Employees (1994) 123 ALR 193). Accordingly, the Commission's award making powers do not extend to making a provision in the terms of clause 5. It follows that a provision of an award in the terms of clause 5 could not be enforced under the Act.

7. Clauses 2 to 4 appear to me to go beyond statements of policy and specify obligations with which an employer is to comply. Accordingly, I think it would in theory be possible to establish that an employer had breached one of those clauses and to sue for that breach under Part VIII of the Act. It may be, however, that a court would, despite the language used in the clauses, interpret them as not imposing enforceable obligations. Even if the clauses were interpreted as imposing enforceable obligations, the consequences of a breach of any one of those clauses seems to me to be negligible. A court may not be disposed to impose more than a negligible penalty for such a breach. Accordingly, cll. 2 to 4 may be practically unenforceable.

8. Assuming the Act is amended by enactment of the Bill, none of the matters referred to in the clauses could constitute an `industrial matter' in relation to which the Commission could make an award. Proposed s.89A(2) of the Act, contained in Schedule 5 to the Bill, sets out exhaustively the matters which can constitute an industrial dispute in relation to which the Commission may make an award. The matters included in the clauses do not fall within the matters listed in s.89A(2). I note that proposed s.89A(5) of the Act provides that `the Commission may include in an award provisions that are incidental to the matters in subsection (2) and essential for the effective operation of the award'. While it is arguable that the matters dealt with in the clauses are incidental to the matters in s.89A(2), they are not essential for the effective operation of an award and therefore would not come within the Commission's award‐making powers.
QUESTION 2
Would any of the clauses contravene proposed Part XA of the Act? In particular:
(i) Would inclusion of any of the provisions in a certified agreement contravene proposed Part XA of the Act?; and

(ii) If inclusion of any of cll.2 to 4 in a certified agreement as presently expressed would contravene proposed Part XA, could any modification or qualifying statements be added to avoid contravention of Part XA? For example, could contravention of Part XA be avoided by including a statement emphasising that employees are free to join industrial associations of their choice or not to join industrial associations and that employees will not be discriminated against or victimised because they are, or are not, members of industrial associations?
SHORT ANSWER

9. In my view, inclusion of all or any of the provisions in a certified agreement would not involve conduct which contravenes any of the provisions of proposed Part XA of the Act. It is therefore not necessary to answer the second part of your question.
REASONS

10. Proposed Part XA of the Act prohibits a range of conduct which may be engaged in by employers, employees or industrial associations. The operation of the proposed Part is described generally in the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and, relevantly, is as follows. The provisions of Division 3 of the proposed Part prohibit an employer from doing, or threatening to do, for a `prohibited reason', or for reasons that include a `prohibited reason', a range of actions, listed in proposed s.298K(1), being actions which harm persons who are employees in relation to their employment. Speaking generally, the prohibited reasons are related to an employee's membership or non‐membership of an industrial association. The provisions of Division 4 of the proposed Part prohibit employees from ceasing work for specified reasons. The provisions of Division 5 of the proposed part prohibit conduct by industrial associations for proscribed reasons against employers, employees and members.

11. Clause 1 does not involve any conduct by an employer, an employee or the SDA. It is simply a statement that the SDA is to have exclusive representation of employees covered by an award. Clause 2 requires an employer to positively promote union membership at the point of recruitment by strongly recommending to employees that they join the SDA. Clause 3 requires an employer to give new employees an application form to join the SDA and a statement of the employer's policy about union membership. Clause 4 requires an employer to give to employees who are not members of the SDA an application form to join the SDA together with a statement of the employer's policy. Clause 5 requires an employer, upon authorisation by an employee, to deduct union dues from an employee's wages and to forward them to the SDA. None of the clauses requires an employer to take any action which is prohibited by the provisions of Division 3 of the proposed part. However, Part XA could be contravened if an employer stated to an employee that the employee would receive preferential or advantageous treatment if he or she joined the SDA or if an employer in fact accorded preferential or advantageous treatment to employees who joined the SDA (see proposed s.298K(1) and proposed s.298L). The clauses do not in their terms involve any action at all being taken by employees or industrial associations. Accordingly, compliance with the clauses could not involve any conduct which contravenes the provisions of Divisions 4 or 5 of the proposed part.

12. I note that proposed Part VIB of the Act, contained in Schedule 9 to the Act, sets out provisions about the making, and certification by the Commission, of certified agreements. Proposed s.l70LT provides for the circumstances in which the Commission is to certify an agreement. Proposed s.170LU sets out the circumstances in which the Commission is to refuse to certify an agreement. Subsection 170LU(2) provides:
`Despite section 170LT, the Commission must refuse to certify an agreement if it is satisfied that:
(a) the employer has, in connection with negotiating an agreement, contravened section 170NB or Part XA (which deals with freedom of association); or

(b) the employer has caused a person or body to engage, in connection with negotiations for an agreement, in conduct that, had the employer engaged in the conduct, would be a contravention by the employer of section 170NB or Part XA; or
(c) a person or body has, on behalf of the employer:

PARA.TAB: (i) so engaged in such conduct; or
(ii) caused another person or body so to engage in such conduct'.

SPEECH.PARA: Whether the Commission must, under s.170LU(2), refuse to certify an agreement will depend on whether any conduct of an employer, or an employer's agent, in negotiating the inclusion of the provisions in an agreement, could constitute a contravention of proposed Part XA. The facts of each case would need to be considered separately to determine whether any such conduct had been engaged in during the negotiation process.
Yours sincerely

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make some remarks at the beginning of the committee's consideration of schedule 18. Senator Murray, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, has raised with the government a number of important points about the human rights of crews on foreign vessels entering Australian waters. It is fair to say that that is a matter that has been raised by a number of other honourable senators. I thank the honourable senator for raising these matters—and, indeed, other honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to state on behalf of the government that we take this issue very seriously. There is no doubt that conditions on some foreign vessels are completely unacceptable. The government is committed to ensuring that crews on foreign vessels in Australian waters are properly protected by Australian law and that all appropriate international standards are adhered to.

In particular, I would like to state clearly that the Australian government is actively working towards the ratification of International Labour Organisation convention 147 which deals with minimum standards for merchant shipping. In accordance with the policy of both the previous and current governments, Australia does not ratify ILO conventions until law and practice are in compliance with the terms of the convention.

We are currently working on ensuring that the law and practice in this area does so comply. This will assist efforts to ensure that the human rights of seafarers are properly protected. Senator Murray has also raised the issue of criminal conduct on board foreign vessels. It needs to be understood that Australian law can apply to offences committed on foreign ships.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond specifically to the point that has been raised by the parliamentary secretary. I had hoped when he set out a moment ago to respond to an approach from Senator Murray of the Australian Democrats he was going to announce a provision—a change; an amendment—to this legislation which would allay the fears of maritime unions as well as many other citizens that their ability to take on the ships of shame is not going to be effectively kyboshed by this legislation. But of course he did not.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation then remains that, if section 18 passes unchanged, and that appears to be the aim of the government and Democrats, the ability of the maritime unions to be able to assess what is going on on ships of shame which come into Australian ports and to act to rectify the violation of human rights on those ships is going to be effectively trammelled.

The ships of shame are that big percentage of the 50,000 merchant ships around the world which ply under flags of convenience, often from places like Liberia or Panama. It is well known in this country at least that conditions aboard those ships fall way short of not only what is expected by Australian standards but also what is expected by international agreements and covenants.

There are heart‐rending cases of seafarers on those ships who have been working, often for more than a year, without any pay at all. If they leave the ship to escape the conditions on it, then they lose the money that they have worked to rightfully obtain, and the wages are very often low. If they stay aboard they are there captive under sometimes slave conditions to unscrupulous ships captains or ships owners from elsewhere in the world.

There have been horrendous cases of appalling conditions of maltreatment and the physical abuse of seafarers. People have been thrown overboard when ships leave ports where there has been a protest about the conditions on those ships. If this proposed section remains as is, it means that the most active people in protecting the rights of seafarers on the ships of shame—that is, the maritime unions in Australia—will lose their ability to effectively boycott work on those ships until the owners come good and do the right thing.

As one member of the unions that have been lobbying in this place to keep their ability to defend foreign seafarers put it, they will be able to do no more than picket on the wharf and hold a placard. You can imagine what effect that will have as far as nefarious captains or owners are concerned; the owners may not even be here but may be looking on from the other side of the world.

A situation will pertain similar to the one that occurred in New Zealand after the industrial relations act was instigated there. When seafarers come into port and tell the local unions that they are not being paid and fed and that they are living in appalling conditions, where there are no showers or working toilets on the ship, all the unions there can do, after the passage of legislation similar to what is now before the Senate in Australia, is say, `We hope that you are going to Australia, because that is one place in the world where you can expect some justice. You can expect justice because the maritime unions over there will come aboard your ship and make sure that the conditions are okay for you. They will not allow that ship to move until it is fixed up.' Any decent Australian will back the ability of the unions to act on behalf of people who have been so terribly treated.

This legislation says that the unions cannot do that any more. If they do, they face a fine of $0.75 million; that is, they face the potential of being destroyed. There is a lot more in this section, and we will get to it. The secretary has led off with the ships of shame. The action of the government and the Democrats in apparently denying the effective action which unions can take in this matter needs to be nailed. In so taking this action, we will be a country where people coming in and working on Australian ports will continue to have their rights violated under both domestic law and international covenants, because these unions will not be able to go to their aid.

The secretary says that the government is concerned about this and will act on it. The question arises as to why that has not happened before. Governments have taken action to make sure that rust buckets are fixed up and that infrastructure is corrected, but when it comes to the human dimension on those ships the recourse to action has been through the maritime unions. This legislation, particularly this insidious proposed section 18, strips the unions of the ability to go to the defence of human rights in our territory in Australia.

I am not reassured, if the Democrats are, by the government saying that it will fix it. I heard that last night when the Greens and people on this side of the House fought to prevent a measure which says that, in the future, those in the workplace will not be able to engage in a work to rules campaign, even if it is a matter of conscience, because their employer must stop paying them if they do. You will be penalised from the minute that you act on a matter of conscience in the workplace, even work to rules campaigns. On that occasion, the Democrats said that it is okay because the government has assured them that, if that happens, the government will bring in some remedying legislation to fix it. It should be fixed before it is brought into place.

Again, this is a case where the Democrats in particular have a constituency, a policy platform and human rights to consider. In this legislation that has been agreed to—the Reith‐Kernot amendment—those human rights are being left to the vagaries of a government promise. That is not good enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to make some broad comments about our fundamental opposition to the reintroduction of the secondary boycotts provision of the Trade Practices Act. There has been some debate up to this point on ships of shame. There was some debate on this during the last sitting week. I intend to make some specific comments about this issue. I am waiting to see Senator Murray's response to the matters that were raised by the Labor senators who spoke on that debate over a week ago and the response of Senator Brown. Senator Murray rose to his feet in that last sitting week and indicated that he shares our concerns on a range of issues to do with ships of shame. I will come to that in a bit more detail shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: The provisions with respect to secondary boycotts, at their core, suffer from the same defects as common law actions in industrial disputes. They are very blunt instruments. They permit employers to access injunctions, including ex parte and interim injunctions, against unions which effectively terminate industrial action, without, at any time, permitting the parties to argue the merits of the dispute. Secondary boycott actions can also lead to massive damages awards. Such damages awards have the potential to prevent an organisation from properly representing the interests of its members because of their fear of being sued out of existence.

The existing act contains provisions which require a 72‐hour cooling off period before action can be commenced, during which time the commission can examine the merits of the dispute and seek to conciliate an outcome. These provisions ameliorate the worst excesses of the secondary boycotts provisions. They strike a proper balance between the rights of the unions to pursue the legitimate interests of their members by industrial action and the need to ensure that unnecessary economic damage is not inflicted on innocent parties.

The opposition's preferred position is the status quo. We make no apologies for that. For the reason I have just outlined, we believe the existing provisions are the most appropriate. Unfortunately, we know the Democrats will not join with us in deleting the secondary boycott provisions. This is very disappointing. The Democrats made an explicit pre‐election commitment to oppose the reintroduction of sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. It was only as a result of the now infamous government‐Democrat deal that the Democrats reneged on their position. There was a ray of light, however, last sitting week in Senator Murray's response to our appeals in respect of the ships of shame issue.

Before I get to that, we have two fall‐back positions. Firstly, we are very concerned about the proposed section 45DB(1). This is not even a secondary boycott provision. It is prohibition on primary boycotts and its terms make it clear that it is specifically directed against the Maritime Union of Australia. The problem is that the provision is so broad it will attack not only the legitimate activities of the MUA but also the legitimate activities of many other trade unions and environmental and consumer groups. The Democrats know this and they will say legitimate protest action will be protected by the proposed defence in section 45DD, but we have grave reservations about that defence. We are concerned that it has been drafted far too narrowly to catch legitimate protest activity by environmental and consumer groups, not to mention trade unions.

There is considerable doubt about the ambit of the provision. This, in itself, is unacceptable, more so because of the sanction that will apply if an organisation discovers that the activities fall inside the prohibition but outside the defence. Given the extraordinary width of the prohibition and the extraordinary narrowness of the defence, we believe this could become a common occurrence, or it may not. Groups will not be willing to run the risk, so they will shy away from what the community would regard as legitimate activity.

BREAK.PARA: One thing is certain about the defence: it will not protect the MUA in any protest about protection of international seafarers. It will not support the MUA in any protest about breaches of international or Australian safety standards. In the previous debate on this matter, I touched on some very heart‐rending examples of exploitation verging on slavery in many areas of the international seafaring industry—some disgraceful stories. Senator Brown has touched on that again today.

My father spent 10 years as a merchant seaman. I certainly would say that the standards of safety and general conditions of employment in the Australian merchant marine shortly after World War II were far better than those which existed in most other parts of the world. I can recall him relating stories to me about his contact in various ports and of the dreadful conditions of employment in many of the ships at that time. Unfortunately, it does not seem to have got any better. In fact, I think we could probably argue in many countries it has got worse, particularly because of the flags of convenience issues. When you try to catch up with the slave like conditions that exist on many of the ships around the world, you find they have shuffled themselves to other world economic centres like Panama and Liberia. The Central African Republic, which is totally landlocked—it does not even have a sea border—has a merchant marine. These are the sorts of disgraceful flags of convenience activities that have been going on. I recall extraordinary heart‐rending stories about the appalling conditions that seafarers underwent at that time and, as I say, it has not improved.

The opposition believes that these are legitimate grounds for protest. We will be moving amendments to ensure that these protests are not prohibited and are not subject to huge sanctions. Why should the defenders of seafarers be subject to huge sanctions in defending the legitimate health, safety and basic human conditions of seafarers, when you cannot catch up with international fleet movers who make massive profits in this area by their appalling exploitation?

Sanctions is the other matter about which the opposition has grave concerns. Injunctions and massive penalties are there and threaten unions. They are there to scare protesters off. Unions which run the gauntlet will risk being sued out of existence. This cannot be right in a democratic society. The other significant amendments we will move will restrict access to injunctions and at least place some cap on damages. Previously I explained the effect of these provisions.

The Democrats, regrettably, have not had the courage to date to oppose the reintroduction of section 45D and 45E. They can at least have the courage here today to knock out the worst excesses of the provisions that are in this bill. I wish it to be noted that, in the fallback amendment that seeks to protect protest action concerning international seafarers, there would be an additional requirement that a certificate had not been issued under section 166A of the proposed workplace relations act.

In effect, this confines the defence even further because a respondent to a boycott will be able to approach the Australian Industrial Relations Commission for a section 166A certificate to, in effect, close off the defence to the other party. This is very much a second‐ or even a third‐best solution but at least it means the commission may have the opportunity to consider the dispute on its merits.

PARA.BREAK: In conclusion, I will seek to incorporate a range of further comments on the amendments, and I wish to make this appeal to Senator Murray. In the last week of the debate, he listened to and acknowledged our concerns over this legislation. He acknowledged we had a point. In this chamber today, we would like to see Senator Murray outline what he is going to do specifically on the amendments before the chamber, not just to protect Australian seafarers and the Maritime Union of Australia but also the other areas I have just highlighted. Senator Murray, we certainly contend that a lot more will need to have come from the discussions between the Democrats and the government over the last week than the very few glib and superficial comments we have received from the parliamentary secretary on this issue. What is Senator Murray going to support today by way of amending and minimising the appal ling provisions with which the government has confronted us? I seek leave to incorporate further comments.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Opposition accepts that these amendments to improve upon the horrendous provisions included in the original Bill. But the Opposition is fundamentally opposed to the reintroduction of s45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act even in an amended form. I have already explained why the Opposition takes this position. We therefore will vote against these amendments.

BREAK.PARA: This amendment deletes this schedule (which removes the secondary boycott provisions from the Industrial Relations Act and inserts them in the Trade Practices Act). I have already explained the reasons for the Opposition's position on this issue.
This amendment is to the same effect as Opp (340) and the Opposition supports it on that basis.

This amendment inserts another element into the defence in respect of s45DB(1). It provides a defence where the dominant purpose for which the conduct is engaged in is substantially related to the protection of international seafarers or to a breach of international or Australian safety standards. I have already explained the reason for this additional defence.

If Opp (340) is not agreed to, this amendment provides that if conduct would otherwise be subject to the Trade Practices Act provisions, it cannot also be subject to actions in tort under State or Territory laws. (This replicates existing provision section 164(1) which applies to conduct which would otherwise be boycott conduct under the existing Industrial Relations Act). This is an existing provision which ensures that unions can not be exposed to "double jeopardy".

If Opp (340) is not agreed to, these amendments qualify the remedies that can be obtained against unions (and officers, members and employees of unions) under the secondary boycott provisions of the Trade Practices Act. Firstly, the amendments qualify the injunction remedy by providing that:

i. an injunction (whether interim or final) cannot be granted in the absence of the other party unless the Court is satisfied that the applicant has given notice of the application to the other person;
ii. an interim injunction cannot be granted unless the Court is satisfied that:
(a) the applicant is likely to succeed at the trial of the action; and

PARA.TAB: (b) not granting the injunction will inevitably expose the applicant to loss or harm for which an award of damages is a wholly inadequate remedy.

BREAK.PARA: Secondly, the amendments qualify the damages remedy by capping the damages which can be awarded as follows:

PARA.TAB: 1. for a union with less than 5,000 members—$20,000;
2. for a union with 5,000 or more members but less than 25,000—$100,000;
3. for a union with 25,000 or more members but less than 100,000—$250,000;
4. for a union with 100,000 or more members—$500,000.

BREAK.PARA: The Opposition moves these amendments as a fallback position. We believe that the "next best thing" is to modify the injunction power so as to considerably reduce its destructive potential against unions. This can be done in two ways—ensuring that an employer cannot "rush off to court behind the union's back" to get an interim injunction; providing very strict requirements before an interim injunction will ordered. This ensures at least that the merits of the dispute will be heard by the Court before an injunction will be ordered. We also believe that the "next best thing" it to place a cap on damages to considerably reduce the destructive potential of unlimited damages. Indeed, when Margaret Thatcher reintroduced common law actions against trade unions she also introduced a cap on the damages that could be recovered. The cap we recommend reflects the amounts introduced by Thatcher.

BREAK.PARA: Schedule 18, item 1, page 251 (line 33) to page 252 (line 6), omit subsection (1) (but not the notes), substitute:

(1) A person must not, in concert with another person, engage in conduct for the purpose, and having or likely to have the effect, of preventing or substantially hindering a third person (who is not an employer of the first person) from engaging in trade or commerce involving the movement of goods between Australia and places outside Australia
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the substantial arguments of the government in relation to this amendment.
Leave granted.

This amendment replaces proposed subsection 45DB(1) of the Trade Practices Act. The provision that appears in the Bill would have prohibited persons, acting in concert, from engaging in conduct where the purpose and effect (or likely effect) of the conduct is to prevent or substantially hinder a third person from engaging in trade or commerce:
between Australia and other countries; or
among the States and Territories; or
within a Territory.

The proposed Government amendment will confine the prohibition in subsection 45DB(1) so that it applies only to conduct the purpose and effect (or likely effect) of which is to prevent or substantially hinder another person from engaging in trade or commerce involving the movement of goods between Australia and places outside Australia.

Some concern has been expressed that the provision, as amended, still imposes a very broad prohibition on conduct that constitutes a primary or secondary boycott. The concern appears to be based on a view that the expression "trade or commerce involving the movement of goods between Australia and places outside Australia" covers a very broad range of activities, because a great many manufacturing and distribution operations have some connection with the export of goods.
The concern is ill-founded. The intention of this amendment is that the prohibition in section 45DB will not apply in respect of the production and distribution of goods within Australia.

The boycott conduct that the section is designed to prohibit is conduct that has been undertaken for a particular purpose and which has, or is likely to have, a particular effect. The purpose and effect of the conduct must be to prevent or substantially hinder a third person from engaging in a particular type of trade or commerce. That is, trade or commerce involving the movement of goods between Australia and places outside Australia. In this context, the use of the expression "trade or commerce involving the movement of goods between Australia and places outside Australia" does not mean merely that the trade or commerce affected includes the movement of goods into or out of Australia, or that the movement of goods into or out of Australia forms some part of, or is related to, the trade and commerce. Rather, it means that the trade or commerce that is affected must entail, or be rolled up with, the movement of goods between Australia and places outside Australia.

The focusing of this prohibition on conduct which affects trade and commerce involving the movement of goods between Australia and places outside Australia reflects the importance the Government attaches to preserving Australia's competitiveness in international trade. Unnecessary delays in the movement of goods can have a profound effect on the nation's trade. The Government believes that strikes and bans unconnected with the wages and conditions of the workers involved must not be allowed to jeopardise international trade, which plays such an important part in our economy.

Boycott conduct involves conduct taken in concert between a first person and a second person. Section 45DB is drafted so that the prohibition does not apply if the target is the employer of the first person. This reflects the Government's policy that where employees engage in boycott conduct with unions, the employees are not to be subject to penalty. Unions engaged in prohibited boycott conduct will be subject to the penalty provisions. However, unions and employees will be exempt from the prohibition where the boycott conduct is directly related to the terms and conditions of employment covering the workplace in which the employees work. This exemption is provided in section 45DD.
Government Amendment No. 164 proposes to also exempt from the boycott provisions conduct, the dominant purpose of which is substantially related to consumer protection or environmental protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —While I have the call, I respond to comments made by Senator Brown and Senator Sherry. Firstly, Senator Sherry directed most of his remarks towards Senator Murray. Senator Brown may not believe that those avenues for redress are substantial enough. As I have already said, this government—as the previous one did—was progressing that both domestically and internationally. We will continue to do so.

Secondly, members of the maritime union or any other person for that matter, including Senator Brown because I know he does take a strong personal interest in this, have the right to bring to the attention of the relevant authorities instances of criminal abuse committed on board ships. In specific response to Senator Sherry, the provisions of section 170DB are not extraordinarily broad. It is not intended to apply to the production and distribution of goods within Australia. Senator Sherry referred to these as `blunt instruments'. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I support amendment No. 163 and I will make my remarks in relation to that amendment and the ones all the way through to No. 170. These amendments represent a significant modification of the original bill and also a significant divergence from the government's stated intention to reinstate the old section 45D. Amendment No. 163 dramatically restricts the use of primary boycotts under the Trade Practices Act. Instead of a general prohibition on primary boycotts affecting trade and commerce, the prohibition will extend only to trade and commerce involving the movement of goods between Australia and places outside it. This provision will pick up only the act of movement; it will not pick up any other aspect of trade and commerce.

SPEECH.PARA: Some commentators have suggested that it will pick up any aspect of trade and commerce if some aspect of that trade and commerce were to involve the movement of goods. I wish to state categorically, as a joint mover of the motion, that this is clearly not the intention of that provision. This provision is targeted purely and solely at movement, at shipping, for example. The reason for that is that primary boycotts on the wharves affect many other people. The effect is not limited to the immediate parties involved. If the waterside workers refuse to load perishable goods, the supplying factory might be forced to suspend operations and stand down workers, resulting in innocent employers and employees being hurt.

That is a similar effect to a secondary boycott in that third parties are involved. That is why the Australian Democrats agreed to that provision being included. We did not agree—and the amendments reflect that—to the coalition's intention to expand movement to include that between states and territories. Wharves and ports are natural monopolies. They are different and require special attention. We would not agree to the extension of coverage to include other primary boycotts. Primary boycotts will remain the responsibility of the AIRC with the retention of the 72 hours cooling off period under section 166A before common law actions can be commenced.

Section 45DB will remain subject to the defence in relation to employment related matters in section 45DD. Indeed, few, if any disputes will be picked up by the provisions given the defence and the broad interpretation which we have insisted on being given in the explanatory memorandum.

Access to section 45DB remedies are further restricted by new section 87AA in amendment 168 which will require that the court must have regard to whether the applicant has taken or could have taken proceedings in an industrial tribunal, particularly in relation to conciliation. This provision, based on section 163N of the current act reflects the importance not just of stopping the boycott but of resolving the underlying causes while balancing the economic damage which might be caused to an innocent third party in the process.

Amendment 164 is a further important amendment. This establishes a full exclusion from 45D, 45DA and 45DB where the dominant purpose of the conduct is substantially related to environmental protection or consumer protection. This exclusion does not exist in the current law. A secondary boycott under the current section 45D of the act, renamed 45DA, prohibits boycotts with the purpose, and likely to have an effect, of substantially lessening competition. The provision will also exclude secondary boycotts under 45D and primary boycotts under 45DB from any action as long as they do not involve industrial action.

The preclusion on industrial action reflects the current Labor law where boycotts under the current Labor Industrial Relations Act are limited to industrial action, thereby precluding any other conduct being picked up. In drafting exclusions, the Democrats have opted not to define what is meant by environmental protection or consumer protection. It is our clear intention in moving these amendments that the clauses be interpreted broadly.
The High Court, in the 1990 case of the Crown v. Murphy, said:
In its ordinary meaning `environment' signifies that which surrounds and long been understood to include the conditions under which any person or thing lives.

Indeed, the High Court has adopted the natural and ordinary meaning of the term. It would, in my view, extend to environmental issues affecting indigenous people, such as the protection of sacred sites. It would extend to urban environment issues and pollution issues. It would extend to environment issues such as preservation of historic buildings. It should and will be interpreted very broadly. It would include boycotts in relation to nuclear issues and the impact they could have on the environment. It would extend to the protection of living things in other countries, such as South‐East Asian rainforests.

Similarly, consumer protection will be given a wide interpretation by the courts. The courts in England—for example, Middlebrook Mushrooms v. TGWU in 1993—and the Australian High Court case of Mengel v. Northern Territory suggest that the courts are prepared to give a very wide latitude to the ability of consumers and protesters to engage in protest action without impinging on secondary boycott or common law tort actions. The Australian courts have, in the past, proved very reluctant to grant injunctions which might impinge on free speech or advocacy, and we would commend that action by them.

The explanatory memorandum also requires a broad interpretation to be given to the term `dominant purpose'. The term `dominant purpose' means the purpose which governs the actions of the relevant person—that is, the `governing purpose'. In adopting this interpretation, we expressly reject the very narrow interpretation used by the Federal Court in the early litigation on section 45D, and note with approval the broader approach of later cases—such as, Justice Von Donassa's interpretation in the GTS Freight Management case v. TWU in 1990.

I note in passing that, since 1995, the Trade Practices Act has had an objects clause which sets the object of the act as simply enhancing the welfare of Australians through the promotion of competition and fair trading and provision for consumer protection. Clearly, the exclusion, read with the objects clause and with section 51(2)A, provides clear guidance that consumer issues are not intended to be restrained by boycott actions. The exclusion will also apply to the National Competition Code by amendment 169—this being the code which the states are pledged to implement in state law as part of competition policy reforms. So this statutory protection for environmental and consumer protection will also be part of state law.

Having made those remarks which are very important as the joint mover of the amendment, I want to deal with some of the issues that have been raised in terms of this ships of shame issue. In doing so, I should note for the record that the correspondence tabled between the minister and us by the ALP was not given to the ALP with my permission, but I do not object to it being tabled.

I have listened with great care to the sincerity and the manner in which the MUA have put their case to me. There are others in the debate who exaggerate the facts and use hyperbole to make points which, frankly, are not helpful in trying to resolve an issue on which there is fundamental bipartisan agreement: on resolving the ships of shame issue. I have not heard any coalition speaker. I have not heard any Green speaker from either of the two Green parties, nor have I heard a Labor speaker, an Independent speaker or an Australian Democrat. I have read the information arising out of the reports of the House of Representatives and there is universal agreement that the ships of shame issues have to be dealt with properly.

When Senator Brown of the Tasmanian Greens raises the issues in the way he does, I am concerned that the exaggeration and the hyperbole may eventually lead to minimising the problem, and that is certainly what I do not want to do. I would make three remarks at the outset. The boycotts to which he refers are illegal right now under the Labor act. Both Labor and the coalition fully supported that secondary boycott legislation under which they are illegal, and they have always been so. Health and safety issues are dealt with by AMSA, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. There is the issue of this huge fine. Unions are not up for fines unless the ACCC launches an action, which it has been capable of doing and has not done for 20 years. Why the workplace relations bill should suddenly result in this huge change is going to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts, the ACCC, as correctly indicated, has only been in existence for one year. But as she well knows, it is the successor to the previous body, the Trade Practices Commission. The head of it is still the same and many of the provisions are precisely the same.

BREAK.PARA: When we are dealing with an issue such as this abuse, how should we deal with it? The concerns raised by the Maritime Union of Australia are real enough and should not be minimised. They do reflect the unions' traditional interest in protecting the welfare of those in their industry who have found it difficult to help themselves. Those concerns are widely shared by a wide number of political and non-political groups.

ILO convention 147 has been isolated by us as being of importance. It has not yet been ratified by Australia. In due course I will seek leave to table a letter from the Labor minister at the time concerning ILO convention 147. ILO convention 147 was not ratified by the Labor government and it has not yet been ratified by the coalition government. There is some doubt as to whether ratification would assist in addressing the full concerns on these ships of shame issues. The relevant operative provision of the convention—article 4—is not mandatory and, in any case, current law and practice in Australia already comes close to exhausting the scope of the powers that can be conferred on the Commonwealth by formally ratifying the convention.

In regard to ensuring that wages and conditions are of an appropriate standard, it would probably be impractical for anyone other than AMSA and the union to pay attention to those. Under international law, the prime responsibility for ships' safety in the wider sense of the term rests with the owner of the vessel and the country where the ship is registered—the flag state. That is our fundamental problem. The ships that come to our shores are not owned by Australians. In articles 27 and 94 in the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea, these articles seek, in part, to protect the sovereignty of flag states and they may bar the further extension of Australian inspection and policing powers. In other words, we have limited rights.

A more practical concern is the number of flag states thought to be in breach of the current conventions. Of concern are the simple practicalities of enforcing existing standards and ensuring that any contraventions are detected and reported in a timely manner to the relevant authorities.

In relation to human rights matters and possible breaches of the criminal law, there is some doubt as to the respective roles that can be played by the Australian Federal Police and the state police. But the Attorney-General and the government are looking at ways and means—and were looking at it under the Labor government—of improving cooperation and interaction by those police services.

A legislative framework already exists for federal-state cooperation in relation to the issues raised. The relevant federal act is the Crimes at Sea Act 1979, which is known as the CAS Act. Complementary legislation applies in the states and the Northern Territory. The last two reports of the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department also refer to a redrafting of the present legislative scheme. A special committee of solicitors-general provided a report in December 1993 proposing a new application of laws regimes for crimes occurring at sea.

The Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, who rejoice in the peculiar acronym of SCAG, adopted that report in November 1994. Draft legislation to implement the new scheme has been prepared by the South Australian Parliamentary Counsel. The draft legislation has been adopted by SCAG as a suitable model. The 1995-96 annual report of the Attorney-General's Department records that negotiations are continuing between the Commonwealth and the states regarding the introduction of the draft legislation. My purpose here is to show you what is being done as opposed to the hyperbole and the exaggeration that we have been subjected to.

In summary, the CAS Act applies the criminal laws of the appropriate state or territory to offences committed on or from Australian ships on overseas, interstate and territory voyages. The CAS Act also applies and prescribes circumstances to offences on foreign ships beyond the territorial sea. The Commonwealth law applies the criminal laws in the adjacent state or territory to offences and offshore areas beyond the territorial sea. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a few brief remarks regarding the proposal for the reintro duction of section 45D and attendant provisions of the Trade Practices Act. At the outset, I wish to fully endorse the remarks made, particularly by Senator Sherry and Senator Brown. I will make some comments about the ships of shame issue shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the proposal here from the government and now supported by the Democrats, contrary to their pre-election promise, is to reintroduce sections that have one purpose; that is, a provocative attack upon the trade union movement in this country. It is clear from the insertion of section 45DB(1), for instance, that unions are to be subject to massive penalty provisions for both primary and secondary boycott conduct, whilst there has been a recognition that other groups are to be exempted.

I do not complain about employees being exempted. That is fair and appropriate. I do not even complain about environmental organisations, be they Greenpeace or whomever, or consumer organisations being given some recognition by way of exemption when they engage in conduct which might otherwise contravene the proposed sections 45D(1) and 45DA(1) and 45DB. But when it comes to action being taken on serious issues—whether they be related to environmental concerns; consumer protection; human rights, which is something that we hear a lot about from the Democrats—or issues which involve some of those considerations and also involve certain industrial considerations such as the ships of shame issue, what we get is this wishy-washy, wimpish attempt by the Democrats to justify what really is a sell-out of the trade union movement.

PARA.BREAK: I make no apologies for the fact that there have been occasions when trade unions in this country have taken action on issues which may not necessarily have been directly related to industrial issues, such as their terms and conditions of employment. For instance, the TWU took action with respect to Air France over Mururoa Atoll. The trade union movement, led particularly by the TWU and the Maritime Workers Union because of their strategic position, took action in respect of the coup which removed a democratically elected government in Fiji. The trade union move ment for years supported action against the repressive regime of apartheid in South Africa in support of UN sponsored and approved sanctions. So there is a long history of this action being taken, and being taken specifically in relation to very important issues.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst Senator Murray gives us a learned opinion here about what may or may not be currently legal or illegal, the fact of the matter is that what we are dealing with in this legislation is a return to the bad old days. They are the days when the coalition conservative government relied upon trade practices legislation to prevent what otherwise is regarded as legitimate industrial and political action by trade unions—often the only groups that can bring about a real change in the circumstances. Who knows, there may be actions required in the future over the abuses of human rights in Burma or Tibet. I would be interested to hear what Senator Murray and the Democrats would have to say if that situation ever comes to pass.

What we have in these provisions, of course, is discrimination against the trade union movement. They are still to be held out as the one group that will be caught by this legislation if they engage in conduct which might otherwise be exempted and, therefore, legal by other groups or by individuals.

I will move very quickly to the ships of shame issue. I think Senator Brown covered it very well in terms of the terrible tragedies that exist in relation to that issue. I believe Senator Campbell was glib in his reply. Whilst he said that the government are concerned about this issue—and we have just heard Senator Murray telling us that he is concerned about it, and we are all concerned about it—the fact of the matter is that they are dragging the chain in terms of trying to do something about it. With indecent haste they are pushing through legislation in this chamber that will stop the one positive action that can be taken by the trade union movement to stop this terrible practice that occurs—at least in so far as it impacts in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you call 46 hours of debate rushing it through?

—What was said, Senator Campbell, is that you agreed this was a very serious issue. What Senator Campbell agreed to on behalf of the government was that in respect of the ships of shame issue you believe the primary purpose involved is a noble one. But, at the same time, you are enacting legislation that will make it illegal for a trade union to take action in support of that primary purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: As any lawyer will tell you, when it comes to a consideration of the provisions of section 45D and E—as they were in the old Trade Practices Act—what is most important is to look at the issue of purpose and intent. I find it hypocritical in the extreme that we have the government saying that the primary purpose of action being taken by the Maritime Workers Union on the ships of shame issue is the highest of ideals and that it is noble but, at the same time, you want to push this legislation through, make it illegal, stop it or else fine the union hundreds of thousands of dollars for doing the only thing that can stop or at least reduce this terrible practice in the maritime sector.

The Howard coalition government is intent on achieving the same objectives. I remind you that in fact it was the Fraser government which stopped sandmining on Fraser Island, which led the international charge to ban commercial whaling and which pioneered the first listings under the world heritage convention—the Great Barrier Reef, Kakadu Stage 1 and Willandra Lakes. Given the significant community discontent about the environmental impact of broadband cable roll‐out which Labor unleashed on the nation, will the government be tightening the laws governing the roll‐out activities of Optus and Telstra in the period before the introduction of the Telecommunications Act—1 July 1997? Will the government ensure that the new Telecommunications Act introduces a tough new set of rules for the building of telecommunication facilities so that the mess Labor left us is finally cleaned up once and for all?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very important question. We are very much aware of the community concern. Indeed, we were aware prior to the last election when we sought to tighten the existing code and the Democrats would not support us, as I recall.
—Rubbish! You didn't support us.
—No. We sought to disallow it, but you would not join us.

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Tierney rightly identifies, the regime that is in place has been there since Kim Beazley, as the minister for communications in 1991, allowed powers and immunities to enable the building of new national infrastructure networks. Let me be clear: it is very important that those networks are in place. I think all Australians want to benefit from lower competitively based telecommunications charges—in other words, cheaper local phone calls. They want to get access to cable television or at least have the option to do so, and they also want interactive broadband services and the Internet. All of those things flow from the revolution that we are seeing and the new infrastructure that needs to be erected.

We have to remember the basis on which that legislation was put in place and the window of opportunity that was therefore provided to the two major carriers and consortiums which then proceeded to embark on $3 bullion to $4 billion roll‐outs. That has been proceeding apace. Let us not have any hypocrisy about Labor's capacity to have tightened the rules. They had every opportunity to do that. They were well and truly briefed. It was well known that the cables would be going overhead more than two years ago.

PARA.BREAK: What we have inherited is a regime that, on the one hand, seeks to ensure people get access to the highest quality range of services but, on the other hand, responds within those constraints to genuine residential concerns. In the context of that, we are not simply doing nothing prior to 1 July, when we will introduce a much tougher regime. I hope to an nounce the details of that in the not too distant future. The highlight of that will be that there will be no more overhead cables unless it is with the permission of the relevant state or territory authority.

ANSWER.PARA: It is quite clear that there will be a fundamental change in approach beyond 1 July. Prior to 1 July, within the constraints I have identified, it is very important to try to minimise the visual impact and the concerns that are expressed by residents about the cable roll‐out. We will stop short of allowing powers of veto, because that would clearly be a breach of the arrangements that were in place and would obviously fundamentally jeopardise the business case of the carriers.

What we have in mind, and what we have been working on for some weeks now on the basis of a public inquiry that we had not so long ago, is to make some significant changes to the current code to tighten it so there are provisions that will seek to improve the situation. For example, it will be necessary for coaxial cable to be grey, not black—one of the things that people often complain about very loudly. It will also be a requirement that carriers use best practice to minimise the potential degradation of environmental amenities and visual appeal associated with facility design and deployment.

In other words, you will have to hide towers wherever you can. You will have to keep them in such a position, you will have to collocate within reasonable limits, so that these things are not intruding all over the place. It will also be a requirement that subscribers have the option to put the cable underground between the street and their home if they are prepared to pay the incremental cost. Subscribers will also benefit from seeing cables go underground at major intersections. So there will be a number of improvements to the existing code. We are committed to those changes, and we are currently working that process through. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from the answer that the minister has no intention of taking any notice of the National Party resolutions. Will you also be ignoring the National Party conference call for an income repayment threshold of $25,000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

Someone may have given them to my office. But I will have a look at them and that, Senator West, in anybody's language, does not translate into saying that I am going to ignore them. I will have a look at them and I will give them due consideration, as I will any representations that are put forward to me on education, employment services or any others.

ANSWER.PARA: Talking about working both sides of the street, Senator West, you are the one who participated in getting rid of some Austudy regulations that were of real benefit to rural students. Then you come in here and try to pretend you are acting in their interests. Get real! You are the one working both sides of the street.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. No doubt the minister vividly remembers presenting Australia's position on greenhouse to the international community in Berlin earlier this year and no doubt he remembers that position was rejected by the vast majority of the world's nations, including the United States. It is true, isn't it, Minister, that Australia was one of just a handful of countries who voted against 137 other countries on setting mandatory or legally binding targets to reduce greenhouse gases? Given the difference between the Australian government's policy and that of the United States on this matter and given Mr Clinton's personal commitment to solving the greenhouse problem, do you expect this issue to be raised in talks tomor row between the Prime Minister and the President?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The meeting I addressed was in Geneva, not in Berlin. Senator Faulkner addressed a meeting in Berlin a couple of years ago. That set us on this path, I have to say, Senator Kernot. Furthermore, we actually did not vote on anything. What we did say in Geneva was that we were committed to Australia playing its part in the global challenge to reduce greenhouse gases. Furthermore, that we believed that to do that successfully the outcome of the Berlin mandate process would have to be one that was fair and achievable. It is for that reason that Australia developed the principle of differentiation, which we are still advancing and on which we are looking for support.

ANSWER.PARA: What I have said in the Senate before—maybe specifically to Senator Kernot—is that not only are we, as a government, seeking to address the need to reduce global warming but also we are committed to expanding economic growth and opportunity. We are not prepared to go down a path that sells off Australian jobs in order to achieve the other objective. We are committed to both—achieving a good global outcome in terms of reducing greenhouse gases whilst, at the same time, giving Australia the opportunity to continue to compete fairly within the international community, giving our economy the opportunity to grow, giving small business, in particular, the opportunity to grow and employ some of the three-quarters of a million Australians who are still out of work.

We do not apologise for the position we have taken. We believe it is the right position in Australia's overall interest. We recognise that it is not easy. We have a difficult task in convincing some of those nations that are advantaged by the terms of the Berlin mandate negotiations in a way in which we are not. Nevertheless, as I said, we believe our argument is sound and therefore we will continue to advance it.

PARA.BREAK: Whether the Prime Minister intends to raise this issue with President Clinton I obviously do not know, but I will pass on to the Prime Minister what I understand to be the senti ment of your question, which is that you would wish him to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, do you expect President Clinton to raise it either directly with the Prime Minister or by way of the speech that he is expected to give on environmental matters in North Queensland later this week? How will the government respond? Isn't this an opportunity for this government to revise its greenhouse position and make an announcement that it will work more constructively with the United States, the international community, on solving the world's greenhouse problems? This is not a domestic issue, is it? This is an international issue. This is about our being responsible international citizens.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that President Clinton has not confided in me as to whether he intends to raise it with Mr Howard, but he may well do so. I do accept that this is an international issue. I said that. It is a global challenge and we all need to play our part. But, Senator Kernot, where you have it wrong is that we are already working constructively with the United States.

ANSWER.PARA: You would be aware of the position of the United States as it has been developed to date, which is for fixed targets, but nevertheless fixed targets that are to be applied flexibly. That is still being worked out in its detail by the United States. In working that out, the United States is dealing with us, is negotiating with us and will continue to do so. We are both committed to a good greenhouse outcome, but I think we are also both committed to economic growth and jobs. (Time expired)

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs
