We will make appropriate decisions with respect to that, Senator Collins. I feel absolutely confident that they will be better decisions than what your government made, because under your government the mess was made and you let Skase get away. As to the specific detail of your question, since you asked it so nicely, I will get you an answer as quickly as I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, given that you cannot give me a precise answer, perhaps you are able to give an assurance that the amount is in excess of $50,000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me repeat what I just said to you a couple of seconds ago: as to the precise detail of your question, as you asked it so nicely, I will get an answer for you as quickly as I can.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Essential Services for Remote Aboriginal Communities

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer the minister to his recent announcement of a pilot project in relation to the provision of essential services to remote communities by the army. I ask: what consultation took place with ATSIC and Aboriginal communities before this announcement was made? Has the minister or his department referred to the May 1994 report by the federal Racial Discrimination Commissioner Irene Moss on the provision of water and sanitation in remote Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and in particular to the finding that there was a lack of community involvement in the choosing and provision of services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Margetts for the question. Consultation occurred with ATSIC, the Minister for Defence, the Minister for Health and Family Services and me. Discussion has ensued. We have a committee established—
—Since you made the announcement.

—Before the announcement was made we met and consultation has been occurring in relation to it. We have studied it and we have also spoken with various reviews that have occurred over a period of time prior to this to establish where the pilot programs will be established. Some preliminary work has already occurred in relation to that.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting, in that regard, to see in today's Courier‐Mail a report from Mr Gary Foley. I see Mr Foley rose to prominence in 1973 as a leader of the Aboriginal protest group which established the tent embassy for six months on the lawns of the then Parliament House in Canberra. Mr Foley was reported as saying:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Indigenous people had not prospered in the past 15 years and have been conned by the ALP's "veneer of tolerance" underpinned by millions of dollars spent with "public relations companies in Sydney and Melbourne".

I like what is going on politically in Australia at the moment. I am glad we have dispensed with the veneer of tolerance that the ALP spent millions of dollars—our dollars—getting public relations agencies in Sydney and Melbourne to come up with big, garbagy PR campaigns—hands across the water; as Australians we should all live together; we shall overcome; all that stuff. Ridiculous promotions.
To quote further from Mr Foley:

With the exception of the Whitlam government—the best politicians, Prime Ministers, governments we ever dealt with in terms of their being straight with what they were going to do with us, was the conservatives—the Liberal-National Party.
Just look at the mediocrity of the past 15 years. We went backwards under Labor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order on relevance. I believe the minister is answering a previous question by Senator Bob Collins. My question was about water and sanitation for Aboriginal communities. I would ask if he could relate to that rather than to something Senator Collins has asked.
—Madam President—
—Order! We need silence so I can hear. Are you wishing to speak to the point of order, Senator Herron?
—No, Madam President, I am going to continue my answer.
—Senator Margetts would prefer you to focus on the particular part of her comments, and I would invite you to deal with it.

—I was just pointing out that all the garbage and rhetoric that went on over the past 13 years is contrasted with what this government is going to do, and that is doing something effective—taking some action. We are going to produce results. Bringing in the army is demonstrably an effective action. We have consulted with them. They are enthusiastic about it. They have the expertise to do it.

ANSWER.PARA: With the HIP program, Ove Arup, who have done a consultancy on this in two states, have shown which areas need water supplies and which need sewerage. As you will know, Madam President, as I have said on previous occasions, there are 80 communities that do not have reticulated water and 120 communities without sewerage. That is the legacy that we have been left by the previous government—13 years they were there, and that is the legacy that they have left us. We are going to do something about it by using the army and getting it to do something effective for those communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. It was a bit unclear at what point ATSIC were involved in the decisions. Perhaps the minister can clarify at what point ATSIC were involved in the decisions. Does this minister see this approval fitting into the existing delivery mechanisms for essential services involving state and local governments? Does the minister not agree that the failure to deliver these services essential to remote Aboriginal communities in the past is more of an indictment of the state and local governments than an indictment of ATSIC?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that over the last 13 years there were more Labor governments in the states in this country than there were Liberal governments. I think it is an indictment of those Labor state governments, just as Senator Margetts has said, and the federal government. They had the opportunity at both a state and a federal level to do something about it.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections.

—Madam President, if I can overcome the interjections from the other side I will answer the first part of the question. ATSIC were involved quite early when the decision was being discussed by the relevant ministers concerned. The speech went through to ATSIC for it to be involved in the development of that speech when it was announced last Friday.

—My question is directed to Senator Hill representing the Prime Minister. Minister, yesterday you confirmed in a written answer to a question of mine that you took on notice on 7 November that the Prime Minister has approved an arrangement which allows his top public servant, Mr Max Moore-Wilton, to earn over $1,000 an hour from his second and third jobs. My question to you, Minister, is how do you explain this extraordinary indulgence to the battlers that you are offering an extra 20c an hour to through your paltry $8 a week pay offer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —As this is really last sitting week's question in which the Prime Minister indicated that he was prepared to accept—
—It was your answer yesterday.

—No, it was your issue of the last sitting week. The Prime Minister indicated that he was prepared to accept a transitionary arrangement in relation to Mr Max Moore-Wilton, who was taking on the job of head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and would, for a period to expire at the end of this year, keep certain tasks which he was undertaking for the Victorian government, if I remember correctly, and for which he was being paid.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, as I recall what the Prime Minister said, to take the public service job, Mr Moore‐Wilton was actually accepting a reduction in pay, presumably—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—I think that you ought to applaud it that people out there who can earn more money in the private sector are prepared to take public jobs because of their commitment to public service. That transitionary arrangement was—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is on relevance. I am not asking a question in similar terms to one that I asked last week. I am asking a new question on the basis of information supplied by Senator Hill yesterday in relation to the fact that Mr Max Moore-Wilton, it has now been found, earns over $1,000 an hour for his jobs. I am asking him how he explains that indulgence when he offers ordinary battlers 20c an hour. That is the question and that is what he should be asked to answer by you, Madam President.

—There was considerable preamble to your question, Senator Faulkner, and it is to that that Senator Hill has been addressing himself thus far, but there is still two minutes and 49 seconds for him to deal with the question.

—The reference to $1,000 an hour is of course misleading, but we know the political purpose for which it is being promoted. The point is this, Senator. What you fail to understand is that you are addressing two different issues. The first issue was your issue of the last sitting week, and that concerned the transitionary arrangements of Mr Max Moore-Wilton and the Prime Minister's acceptance of those because Mr Moore‐Wilton was willing to take a public service job at a lower salary, something I would suggest that all honourable senators should applaud. That was the point I was making to Senator Faulkner when he was determined to interrupt. The fact that there are some within the private sector who have the potential to earn more money and are prepared to forgo that because of a commitment to public service is something that should be commended.

ANSWER.PARA: The second half of the question related to the government's decision about the safety net wage rises. That answer was given by Senator Alston yesterday in relation to another question. That is, because of the low inflationary environment, we have been able to establish lower rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Establish!

—We have been able to establish lower interest rates. There have been two official drops in interest rates since we have been in government. We are able to provide for lower income earners and give them some certainty with the $24 increase over three years. They would not have been able to achieve that under Labor. At the same time, we are reasonably guaranteeing that they will keep it in their pocket. What happened under Labor was that they got the pay rise, but it was eaten up with taxes, inflation and interest rates. That is the difference between the last Labor government and this government. The difference is that when workers get the money now, they get to keep it, because of low interest rates, low inflation and lower taxation. That ought to be applauded.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it not true, Minister, that you confirmed yesterday that Mr Max Moore-Wilton has attended six Southern Hydro and five Public Transport Corporation board meetings over a seven-month period since his appointment as Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, that the average duration of those meetings was three to 3.5 hours and that he has been earning over $1,000 per hour? How do you and the Prime Minister justify allowing the head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet to hold three jobs when the same man, Max Moore-Wilton, is costing so many public servants in PM&C and elsewhere their only job?

—Either Senator Faulkner is deliberately failing to appreciate what I said or, to give him the benefit of the doubt, simply does not understand. I said that a transitionary arrangement was permitted on the basis that this man was significantly reducing his salary in order to perform public service, working in a highly responsible job as head of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet for the benefit of this government and the nation. That is something that ought to be recognised and applauded.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer the minister to his Lyons Memorial Lecture last Friday in which he said that the special auditor process which looked at accountability questions in Aboriginal affairs was of particular value to ATSIC. The minister also said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: We must encourage value for money in the delivery of programs.
Could the minister expand on the government's policy in this area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Ellison for the question. There can be no doubt that the special auditor process was extremely valuable to ATSIC, the government and the indigenous community as a whole. As I said in my speech on Friday, ATSIC has told me that the findings of the special auditor will be useful to it in improving grants administration. Perhaps equally importantly, it will enable me to assure the indigenous community, my colleagues in government and the wider Australian community that accountability in ATSIC is as high as in any other area of government.

ANSWER.PARA: As senators will recall, the special auditor had completed a review of approximately 95 per cent of ATSIC funded organisations when the process stopped. Only 11 per cent of the organisations reviewed were in full compliance with grant conditions. The special auditor expressed serious concerns regarding 292 of the 1,252 organisations reviewed. Those organisations received $172 million in funding in their last year of funding receipt.

Senators may also recall that I undertook to provide details of the final costs of the special auditor when they became available. I have been informed that the final cost of the special auditor is $1,556,315. That cost comprises $1,232,600 for professional fees for the review of organisations; $135,999 in management and reporting fees; $164,149 in out‐of‐pocket expenses; and $19,370 in additional training costs due to ATSIC officers in Perth and Melbourne rescheduling reviews, which was agreed to by ATSIC in advance. There was also $4,197 billed as precontract variation fees which is still being discussed. The cost will be met from ATSIC's running costs and will not impact on any program activity.

The cost of the special auditor was higher than initially estimated because the complexity of the task proved greater than first assumed. The cost of scrutinising organisations about which there were compliance concerns was much higher than that of blemish free organisations. Only 11 per cent of organisations were blemish free. ATSIC has allowed a figure of $1.18 million for the special auditor in their budget this year.

By any measure, the special auditor provided excellent value for money and will greatly improve outcomes by ensuring that money no longer goes to organisations that are not accountable. As I mentioned earlier, ATSIC has advised me that they found value in the special auditor process. It has provided lessons in accountability requirements and in the importance of training and monitoring outcomes and performance rather than just financial inputs. It raised issues about the number and small size of many organisations that ATSIC funds. ATSIC also advised me that they are closely monitoring those organisations which have been the subject of serious accountability concerns. I intend to discuss the matters raised by the special auditor with the new board of ATSIC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister explain how accountability managed to slip so badly that only 11 per cent of organisations were in full compliance with their grant conditions?
—That is rubbish. You are still running this garbage, are you? Read the report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that Senator Collins read today's Courier‐Mail , where Mr Gary Foley says that the critics of Aboriginal affairs do have a point.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to rule Senator Herron out on the basis of tedious repetition.
—There is no point of order.
—On the point of order: there needs to be repetition. This fact cannot be got through to the previous government, which was in power for 13 years and produced the desperate situation that exists.
—I have ruled on the point of order. You may complete answering your question.

—Thank you, Madam President. The situation was allowed to develop under the previous government. The previous government had one policy for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs and that was to blindly spend without any thought of gaining value for money. There was no consideration of outcomes, no attempt to find out what was or, in their case, what was not being achieved. They just stood back and threw fistfuls of money into the air and hoped that the problems facing indigenous Australians would go away. Mr Foley, for example, said that all indicators such as blacks in prison, deaths in custody, unemployment and health problems were as bad now as they were 20 years ago. In the past 12 years, Labor poured over $12 billion into indigenous affairs at a Commonwealth level. I do not quibble with that level of expenditure. Indigenous Australians are the most disadvantaged. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister in the Senate. Minister, has Mr Max Moore‐Wilton completed his reports to the Prime Minister on the ministerial guidelines on conflict of interest and on the tender rort for the guns buy‐back scheme? If not, when are these reports expected to be completed and will the minister seek an undertaking from the Prime Minister that these reports will be made public?
—There was a false premise in the question, Madam President, in that there was no tender rort. Therefore, the balance of the question does not deserve an answer.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. As the minister has failed to answer the question, I also ask: when he investigates the matter will he seek an assurance from the Prime Minister that Mr Max Moore‐Wilton will not be paid further consultancy fees for undertaking this task on behalf of the government?

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Telstra: Community Service Obligations and Directory Assistance

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, do you stand by your comments made on numerous occasions to the effect that community service obligations and, in particular, free directory services, will not be diminished by either the Telstra sale or any other current telecommunications reforms? Are you aware that, as from yesterday, Telstra has reduced its directory assistance so that it no longer provides addresses and will no longer give telephone numbers to those who require a high level of assistance or do not have the exact address?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the community service obligations which, as you well know, are enshrined in both the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1996 and the telecommunications package will certainly remain in place. We are very much committed to them. As far as the changes to directory assistance are concerned, I am sure you are aware that, at the present time, Telstra receives something in the order of 400 million directory assistance calls per year. Ninety‐six per cent of those relate to inquiries about phone numbers. The other four per cent—in other words, about 20 million—range from inquiries concerning not only addresses, but even things like recipes or the weather and all sorts of other extraneous information.

ANSWER.PARA: It is understandable that Telstra is particularly concerned to ensure that people have immediate access where possible. The benchmark that is set in a number of overseas countries is around 10 seconds for answering those calls. To have the system clogged up by people who are effectively using it for purposes for which it was never designed simply deprives others of the opportunity of getting numbers as quickly as they should.

Clearly, we need to make special arrangements for the visually impaired and print handicapped because they do not have the ability to access White Pages. Therefore, special arrangements will continue for those people. I think you ought to acknowledge, given that it is a free service, that the numbers are growing in the order of 20 to 25 per cent a year. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) to a question without notice asked by Senator Tierney today, relating to the roll‐out of telecommunications cable by Optus and Telstra.

In the answer the minister gave he probably ran out of time to give all the information to his own dorothy dixer about what appears to be new government policy on this issue of cabling. Therefore, my comments are to try to seek more information or get clarification from the minister, if I understand correctly what his announcements were when he answered the question from Senator Tierney.

As I understand it, the minister outlined the fact that the national code would be amended to take account of new arrangements the government wished to put into place to ameliorate some of the community hostility about overhead cables. Amendments to that code would take place between now and 1 July next year when presumably the post‐1 July 1997 Telecommunications Act would come into place.

In particular I note that the minister said that it would be a requirement under the new code for carriers to place the cables underground at intersections. What I am interested in in particular is how that will be imposed under the code. If carriers refuse between now and 1 July to put the cables underground as they continue the roll‐out, will they be eligible for any penalty for breaking the code that the minister outlined? What will that penalty be? How will it be imposed? In addition, I am intrigued to seek further information from the government about whether, if there is going to be a penalty, the penalty will require amendment to the legislation? For example, there is speculation in today's Financial Review that, if the code is broken, fines of up to $10 million may be imposed against the carrier who breaks the code.

I would certainly like clarification as to whether such a penalty can be imposed under the code. From my reading of the present legislation, it makes no mention of penalties. Do there have to be amendments under the legislation so that some authority can impose the penalty? The government should clarify quickly what is required in this area.

If it is possible through this code between now and 1 July to tell the carriers to go underground at an intersection with cabling, why cannot the code also be used between now and then to tell carriers to go underground everywhere, or have the carriers agreed voluntarily from now on to go underground at an intersection? If they refuse between now and 1 July, how will the minister apply the penalty for it? The minister has opened up the matter by his answer. I agree that he ran out of time; there may have been further information coming. I am raising these further queries in the hope that he may be able to answer some of them because, at the moment, there may be confusion.

I also note that, in the press reports today, some government backbenchers—a Mr Hardgrave and a Mr Neville—have both said that the issue that has been outlined here by the minister is still not the end of it as far as they are concerned. Although the Prime Minister appears to have rejected Mr Abbott's suggestion of a telephone levy, Mr Hardgrave in the Herald‐Sun today said that the idea would not go away and that one option would direct contributions from three levels of government.

PARA.BREAK: It appears that there is still genuine debate going on amongst the minister's own govern ment and amongst his own backbench, and I do not decry that. That debate is going on in the community; it is going on in all political parties. The real issue I want to hear about from the minister, if it is at all possible today is: how can he impose a penalty or a direction on putting cables underground at an intersection under the present code? I would be very appreciative of an answer to that. If we do not get a reasonable answer, I think it will create more confusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that Senator Schacht is confused. I will do my best to try to lift that veil of ignorance.
—I want to make sure others are not confused. I gave you the option to clarify.

—I am grateful to you for the supplementary question. I have not had a supplementary question from the other side of the chamber for quite a while. In fact, this is unique, so I am grateful to you. I will do my best to assuage your concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, in relation to intersections, what I said was major intersections, not every intersection. Therefore, the obligation would be on the carriers from the time that the tightened code is introduced to go underground at major intersections.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who defines `a major intersection'?

—That will be a matter for the drafting. We are establishing the principles at this stage of the game. I do not think that it is beyond the wit of mankind to work out precisely what a major intersection is. There are some definitions that describe it as the conjunction of two or more main roads, but there may be a choice of definitions that we will have to look at. We are establishing the principle.

SPEECH.PARA: You ask whether it is possible to include the penalty provisions in the code. Indeed, my advice is that it is. Because the code is a licence condition and a breach of a licence condition constitutes a breach of the Telecommunications Act, you would be able to take action against a carrier who did not comply with that requirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you change the licence definition during the period they have the licence?
—Yes. You can change licence conditions at any time.
—And they can't sue?

—No. There is always the prospect of additional obligations being imposed. One as you suggested that somehow my announcement today constituted a rejection—I think that was what you said—of what had been said either by the Prime Minister or Mr Hardgrave or others—
—I just commented he appeared to reject the levy yesterday.

—Yes, but I think you said that what I said today is a rejection of the levy concept, and it has nothing to do with the levy concept. That is, if you like, the longer term issue. As we both know, there are a number of people in the community who think there are various ways of taking that issue further. What the Prime Minister did was to make it crystal clear that he did not see merit in the concept of an additional in charge on local telephone calls. What was being reported in the paper was that there are other possibilities that could be explored. They are not on the table, so those issues are entirely hypothetical. I am simply responding to the way in which you, I think, characterised my comments.

SPEECH.PARA: You asked: if you can stop them from going underground at major intersections, why cannot you stop them going underground everywhere? We get back to the fundamental issue here, which I know you are very much aware of, and that is that the carriers have their rights. They have been in place since 1991. They have built their business cases accordingly. They have incurred significant supply contract obligations. They have embarked upon strategies for roll‐out. They have obviously taken all of that into account as far as the imminent float of Optus Communications is concerned and to move the goal post or fundamentally change the rules well into the final quarter would be a devastating rejection and would leave the government open to liability on a number of fronts.

TALK.START.PARA: —But not for major intersections it wouldn't be a liability?

—No. It is a judgment you make. Basically we are saying that there are some ways in which you can impose a bit of fine-tuning, but against the background of accepting that you do not have the right to stop the roll‐out prior to 1 July. But come 1 July it will be a very different ball game. You will be able to. In fact, the legislation will provide that you are not allowed to have any more aerial roll‐outs of new infrastructure unless it is approved by the relevant state or local authority.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that there is always a balance to be struck in these things. The tightening of the code in a number of respects will cumulatively have a financial impact on the carriers. You have to be careful that you do not push too far. Quite clearly, what we do want in this country is a competitive model. We do want vigorous competition in all of the services that will be available. Therefore, you do not want to push to the point where that is in jeopardy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rather amazed that Senator Schacht got up and spoke on this matter. It was a very important question and a devastating answer from Senator Alston. I was surprised when comments came about that following question time. Let us make it perfectly clear who is the guilty party in this matter. It is the Labor Party. Where were they? What were they possibly thinking of when they set up this system back in the early 1990s?
—You supported it, you fool.

—There were a whole range of people on the other side, including Senator Collins, who was one of the merry‐go‐round of ministers. Perhaps this was the problem. They kept changing their minister for communications every six months. Senator Collins got left with the parcel longer than anyone else, if I recall. They kept changing their ministers and obviously no-one was in control of the ship and no-one was actually noticing what was happening with this. Roll‐out technology has been around for a very long time. People know what cables look like. You were the government of the day, Senator.
—You are the government now.
—I know we are the government now. We are now charged with trying to clean up the mess that you and your people made on this matter.
—Read the Hansard . You supported it.

—I have read the Hansard . I went through all the Telstra inquiries and I listened to all the evidence. In theory, it was all supposed to be about the sale of Telstra. But most people wanted to talk about the terrible mess that the former Labor government left when it allowed the carriers to roll‐out overhead. Senator Schacht, who was on the inquiry, was incredibly embarrassed day after day when we used to ask the witnesses, `Who is responsible for all of this?' They would say, `The Labor Party.'

SPEECH.PARA: What were their advisers doing when they did not inform the government, or the government did not even bother to ask, what was going to be the environmental impact of setting up a system where you had these ugly cables—it was shown overseas that they were ugly cables—strung right around the major cities? It is a party that claims that it has great concerns for the environment. Obviously, it had no concern for the environment when they set up a regime where the particular companies did not have to comply with any state environmental laws or any local planning laws.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's been the case since federation.

—Yes, but we have not been quite rolling out this, have we, Senator? You might have thought that with new technology there was another way to do it. There are two ways to do it. One is to set up a better interconnect arrangement between Telstra, Optus and the other players. If you had done that, perhaps we would not have had to go through all this nonsense. The other way to do it would be to collocate the cables underground. If you had set that up in the early 1990s, we would not be in this mess at the moment. When Optus was developing its business plan, it would have had to take that into account.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a bit rich to be interjecting on this issue when the whole roll‐out was authorised by your government. We are now the government that has to try to fix up this mess. As Senator Alston indicated, beyond 1 July next year there will be a whole new set of regulations. This government will be protecting the environment by what we do in relation to local planning laws and what we do in relation to making these companies accountable to state environmental laws.

In the meantime, we are going to try to tighten up the national code so that the damage that your government left is not too horrific. There are a number of alternatives which we are now considering which can be put in place before this mess that you have allowed to develop across the major cities of Australia continues. The former government is responsible for this mess. You should hang your head in shame. I am amazed that you have the temerity to get up on your feet and speak about it when you created the mess in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a bit surprised that Senator Schacht had to question the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) regarding major intersections. If you have some way of directing the carriers to go underground and have major intersections, it should be the same elsewhere. The point about major intersections—indeed, all intersections—is that there may be compelling reasons why you have to go underground anyway. From what I have seen of the roll‐outs to date, they are generally underslung. They are generally underslung for the conductors that are already there for other purposes, whether they be power or some other cables.

SPEECH.PARA: As you probably know, you have to have minimum clearances at intersections, whether they are major or not. If you are going to undersling cables below what is already there, you can probably get down below the minimum. Generally, the minimum for overhead in most states is 6.6 or 6.7 metres or something like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to get a wheat truck under it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it has been a spectacle here this afternoon. We have watched the two major parties accuse and counteraccuse one another of being guilty over this issue. SPEECH.PARA: As I suggested in this place yesterday, the government could start by instructing Telstra to put its cables underground. Much has been said this afternoon, both by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) and by members of the government, about a national code and the need to `tighten up'. I think that was the phrase that was used. As I understand it, the minister already decided some time ago to abandon the national code. The senators need to be reminded that we have already had two attempts, neither of which was satisfactory to anybody. In fact, there are plenty of arguments that suggest the second attempt was no more satisfactory than the first one.
I would like to take the opportunity today to read from some of the hundreds of letters that I have received on what people think about the situation. The letter states:

The City of Unley does not accept the view, "that nothing can be done". Information available to us strongly suggests that not only will the cable roll out activities of Optus and Telstra be more costly in the longer run, but they will be contrary to a State which promotes itself as a technologically "smart State".
We suggest that with cooperation between all three levels of Government, together with Optus and Telstra, that a most satisfactory outcome could be achieved for our South Australia.
It goes on. The city of Mitcham in South Australia says:

. . . this Federal Government inherited the rules governing the matter in which telecommunications networks are rolled out. This is generally understood, and even former Labor Party members such as Senator Chris Schacht and Kim Carr have conceded the former government "got it wrong"—
They got it wrong—
when they framed this legislation.
However, the Australian community is not concerned about whose fault the current inadequate legislation is—
I think we might disagree with that point from the Democrats.
However, I will go on—

They are concerned about how this Government will allow this inadequately regulatory framework to continue, resulting in more and more urban streetscapes being ravaged by thick ugly cables which are outdated and unnecessary.
I have another letter. This time it is from the city of Burnside. It states:

The overwhelming majority of our residents do not believe that the provision of advanced telecommunications justifies the use of aerial cabling for construction of cable networks. A survey conducted in the City showed that three quarters of the population hold this view and the number of complaints and queries we constantly receive from residents only reinforce Council's view that there is serious disquiet in a large proportion of the community, about the liberty telecommunications carriers have under the current legislative framework to erect aerial cabling despite community objection.
I could go on reading from the letters that I have, and they are much along these lines.

What I heard this afternoon from the minister is that all it needs is some finetuning, that we should not push too far and that we should be encouraging a competitive model. But I ask: what about the consumers? Nobody has gone to them and said, `Is aerial cabling acceptable to you. Are you prepared to pay a little extra to put it underground? Do you want your trees demolished in your street in order to make way for cables?' The answer is no. At no stage has the government, either this government or the former government, asked people from the community for their own views about this.

So tightening up the code will not be an answer to this problem. Turning the black wires into grey ones will not be an answer to the problem. Certainly saying that major or minor or intermediate intersections should have it underground will also not save those trees in people's streetscapes. It will not solve the problem of the visual blight that aerial cables are providing to our streetscapes.

So I think this afternoon's spectacle of accusation and counteraccusation simply demonstrates to the community that nobody is willing to take the necessary steps on the part of the government to solve this very serious problem—one which a very large community in Australia is very much opposed to.

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that any reform to Australia's system of industrial relations should recognise the special needs of employees to be protected from disadvantage, exploitation and discrimination in the workplace.

We the petitioners oppose the Coalition policies which represent a fundamentally anti‐worker regime and we call upon the Senate to provide an effective check and balance to the Coalition's legislative program by rejecting such a program and ensuring that:
1. The existing powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) be maintained to provide for an effective independent umpire overseeing awards and workplace bargaining processes.

2. The proposed system of Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs) should be subject to the same system of approval required for the approval of certified agreements (through enterprise bargaining). Specifically, an AWA should not come into effect unless it is approved by the AIRC.

3. The approval of agreements contained in the legislation should be public and open to scrutiny. There should be provision for the involvement of parties who have a material concern relating to the approval of an agreement, including unions seeking to maintain the no disadvantage guarantees.
4. Paid rates awards be preserved and capable of adjustment, as is currently the case in the legislation.
5. The AIRC's powers to arbitrate and make awards must be preserved in the existing form and not be restricted to a stripped back set of minimum or core conditions.
6. The legislation should encourage the processes of collective bargaining and ensure that a certified agreement within its term of operation cannot be over‐ridden by a subsequent AWA.
7. The secondary boycott provisions should be preserved in their existing form.

8. The powers and responsibility of the AIRC to ensure the principle of equal pay for work of equal value should be preserved in its existing form. We oppose any attempt by the Coalition to restrict the AIRC from dealing with overaward gender based pay equity issues.
9. A `fair go all round' for unfair dismissal so that all workers currently able to access these remedies are able to do so in a fair manner, at no cost.
10. Workers under state industrial regulations maintain their rights to access the federal awards system in its current form.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to reject the above proposed reforms to the area of industrial relations.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we condemn the Federal government's proposed changes to HECS whereby the law degree will be placed in the highest HECS tier of the differential system for students commencing in 1997. We deplore this action for the following reasons:
1. The differential HECS system is inherently inequitable in that it exacerbates existing disadvantages confronting many students.

2. Law faculties have long been funded at the lowest level of the Relative Funding Model. As a result law faculties have been increasingly under‐resourced and over‐crowded, compromising the quality of legal education.

3. Course costs cannot be used to justify placing law in the highest category. Such a system places law students at a double disadvantage—high levels of HECS and inadequate resources. Furthermore, the majority of law students are also required to pay considerable amounts for their practical legal training, and as such already face a significant financial burden.

4. Law courses lead to a variety of occupations such that there are vast earning differences between law graduates regardless of whether they are in the legal profession or otherwise. The reality is that 50 per cent of law graduates will not enter the legal profession.
We strongly oppose the Federal Government's cuts to higher education funding and proposed alterations to HECS.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, most humbly ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, abandon these destructive policies immediately.

PETITION.TITLE: Unions

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Schacht proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The recent impacts of the Liberal Governments draconian cuts to the ABC which include a dramatic effect on the programming output of the national public broadcaster and in particular ABC Radio.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Schacht, I indicate that I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times for each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clock accordingly.
—I rise to support the MPI standing in my name.
—Which is being broadcast on the ABC.

—That is dead right but, if your government gets its way, there will be a lot less broadcasting on the ABC in the years ahead, with the draconian cuts that you have outlined and have imposed on the ABC as a clear and absolute breach of your own election promises only eight or nine months ago.

BREAK.PARA: I want to remind the Senate that the coalition government said during the election campaign earlier this year:
The Coalition will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC.
That was in their better communications policy statement of 18 January 1996. They also said:
The Coalition will maintain the current prohibition on advertising and sponsorship on ABC television and radio.

To make sure there was no doubt about this, on the night of the election after the result of the election was clear, Senator Alston, the incoming communications minister, was asked a few questions in the tally room by ABC reporter Jim Middleton:
First of all the commitment close to home about the ABC and the commitment to maintain funding in real terms over the term of the coming parliament, does that stand?
Alston: Absolutely.
There was no equivocation, no qualification. He said, `Absolutely.' Jim Middleton then asked:
Even if you discover on Monday that the budget's bottom line is much worse than the government's been saying?
Alston: Oh yes. I think John Howard's made it very plain that we want to maintain—honour—all our commitments and the ABC is a very important part of that.
That promise has been comprehensively broken.

At the Senate estimates committee hearing a month or so ago, when Senator Alston was asked about this clear breach of his own promise both as a shadow minister on the night of the election and when it became clear that he would be the new minister, he said, `Well, you have to understand that my words were affected by the euphoria of the moment.' It seems to me the word `euphoria' is probably a description for the fact that he might have had too much to drink. I do not know. That was the only limp excuse he could give. The `euphoria of the moment' meant that he said `absolutely'. He did not qualify it in any way.

Since then, we have seen the impact on the ABC. Why this opposition has moved this very important matter of public importance today is that in recent weeks we have started to see the impacts of the first cuts to the ABC, not the total cuts. We have seen the impact on the ABC and the reduction of programs particularly in radio and metropolitan radio as a result of the efficiency dividend cut across the board, which was about $11 million for this year of 1996-97.

What is yet to come to the ABC is the imposition of the cut announced in July of this year by the government of $55 million over the subsequent three years. It means a $209 million cut to the ABC over the next four years—$209 million, a clear and absolute breach of their own promise.

What we have seen already, with the first cut of $10 million, is massive bleeding, massive haemorrhaging, in the ABC. Goodness knows what is going to happen next year when the first of the $55 million cuts will be imposed on this great national broadcaster that has been operating since the early 1930s and is recognised worldwide as one of the best of two or three national public broadcasters.

We have seen around Australia in the last few weeks changes in broadcasting at metropolitan radio stations. These changes have been quite dramatic and have created real concern for the community as well as for the ABC. The stations being affected are: 5AN in Adelaide, in my own state; 3LO in Melbourne; 2BL in Sydney; 4QR in Brisbane; 6WF in Western Australia; 7ZR in Hobart; and 8DDD in Darwin. They are the major AM band radio stations that provide quality community information—quality interviews, including some talkback, on current events of interest to the broad range of the community.

You do not get that quality with commercial broadcasters that are driven purely by ratings and talkback that is aimed at reinforcing what the listener wants to hear. The ABC quality radio stations that I have listed are about providing extra and additional information to improve the quality of discussion about these issues in the community.

The first $10 million in cuts is being directed at those radio stations. We know this fits the political agenda of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who wants Australians to feel comfortable and relaxed and who does not want the ABC broadcasting things that he describes as politically correct or what he described last night in his Menzies memorial lecture as so-called people who wear a black armband for Australian history.

John Howard again outlined last night that he thinks the best time for Australia was in 1955 when the Menzies regime was at its height. That is what he hankers after. That is what he believes was the best time in Australia. It is an extraordinary position to have a Prime Minister in the last five years of the 20th century saying that the best time was nearly 40 years ago in the middle of the Menzies era, that this is what we should try to emulate. I do not think there are many people in Australia across the board who would like to go back to that time, unless you happen to be in a particular small segment of Australian society who dominated the way the country was run.

That is why the attack has come upon these radio stations so that quality broadcasting comes to an end. In my own state the horrendous attack of these cuts is on 5AN. This is in a state that has one monopoly daily newspaper, owned by News Limited, the Adelaide Advertiser, which under no description could be said to be providing a broad base of community discussion. The ABC in Adelaide is the only alternative major voice for news and commentary for a population of over one million people.

Keith Conlon, one of the most successful broadcasters on 5AN for many years, has announced that he is resigning from the position at the end of this year. He said that the cuts make it untenable. Last week the Adelaide Advertiser gave coverage for the first time in detail—and I have to compliment the Adelaide Advertiser; I wish they would do more of it—of what was happening to the ABC in South Australia. The article stated:
Conlon believes that cuts to 5AN are being generated for the "most cynical" of reasons—fear of hard questioning from politicians who dislike the ABC.
"If you ask well-researched questions, you are regarded as the enemy," Conlon says.
"Elements of the Coalition are not interested in vigorous questioning, which should be applied to any political party. Serious analysis makes you part of the enemy."

That is what Keith Conlon said in Adelaide last week. It is one of the reasons he is leaving. One of the other journalists, Matt Abraham, is losing his position because right across the board mid‐morning and late morning programs on metropolitan radio have been combined into one as a cost cutting measure. That is the period when most people are listening to ABC radio.

Some of the most successful radio programs are being cut. Whether it is 5AN, 2BL or 3LO, they are all being cut and reduced in their ability to provide a forum for people to air important issues—issues that probably do make the present Prime Minister uncomfortable and less relaxed but important issues for all Australians.

Turning to 2BL, we find a station that services 600,000 or 700,000 listeners every morning. A program format developed by the late great Andrew Olle is now being destroyed because of the imposition of these cuts. This station does all of this with 31 staff. There are very few radio stations in the world that service a listening audience of this size with this quality with only 30 staff. It is not overstaffed. There are not slackers and people sitting in back rooms doing nothing in the running of 2BL. It is a very efficiently run radio station, as are all the metropolitan radio programs. But they are being targeted first in these cuts and we are going to see a reduction in the quality of the ABC as a result of these savage cuts by the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this afternoon to oppose the motion and to speak about `our ABC' but from a very different perspective to that presented by Senator Schacht. Our view of the ABC is all about the future. It is about government creating the conditions for creative renewal. It is about positioning the corporation for what will be a radically different environment. It has everything to do with assisting the ABC to reposition and redefine itself as a first class public broadcast er, one that defines and reflects who we are and what we aspire to as a community.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me outline why there is every reason to be optimistic about the future of the ABC. Surely by now there cannot be anyone left in the community who sincerely doubts the government's commitment to the ABC. There is a compelling case to be made for a public broadcaster of independence and integrity. Nothing the government has done threatens the integrity or the future of the organisation. Although the ABC ought to be preserved, and the government is committed to this outcome, it cannot be frozen in time, impervious to change and the real world of technological change, if it is to be the vital cultural organisation all Australians want it to be.

It is important to recount the positive steps taken by the government towards allowing the ABC a real opportunity for change without damaging changes to what it produces. To start with, the government has maintained its commitment to current levels of funding to the ABC, subject to the two per cent cut to running costs which was generally applied to all government departments and agencies. This of course reflects and responds to the fiscal mess the government inherited from Labor.

No credible case could be made to quarantine or exempt the ABC from these reductions. It could not be seriously suggested that other programs such as education, health and hospital allocations should bear a disproportionate cut and leave the ABC untouched. In any event, the ABC will receive in total approximately $531 million of taxpayers' money in 1996-97 and approximately $496 million in 1997-98.

Despite dire predictions, the sky has not fallen in—contrary to what Senator Schacht has said. Those more measured in response are quick to see the opportunity for the ABC to make improvements, to make efficiencies, to develop a streamlined operational structure and to become better focused, better able to deliver quality services and activities and be able to justify the cost to the taxpayer of maintaining it.

Perhaps it should come as no surprise that, despite the hand-wringing of Senator Schacht, when Mr Gareth Evans was communications minister way back in 1988, he outlined an approach for the ABC which sounds uncannily familiar. In 1988 he said:
We simply cannot seriously or sensibly address the question of funding for the ABC without at the same time looking seriously or sensibly at its role and objectives.

One might echo a well‐known retort of a former Labor leader—`What are they going on about?' Only the wilfully misinformed or the most flagrantly self-interested would suggest that there is no room for change and improvement in the ABC. To attribute cuts in programming to funding cuts is going off half‐shot, if I may say so. It is a false premise which fails to establish the causal connection between program changes and funding cuts.

Take radio for instance. The changes that have occurred to programming within ABC radio have not been made by the government. We have said it a number of times before, but it bears repeating: ABC management is autonomous; the ABC board is independent; the government does not control programming. Many of the hard decisions that the ABC has taken, the decisions that have seen changes in radio programming, have resulted from the ABC's own $13.5 million budgetary blow‐out, not the government's decision to reduce funding by two per cent in line with across-the-board measures. This has meant the taxpayer has had to find another $13 million, and another $13 million added on the national debt. Well before the budget, the Managing Director of the ABC, Mr Brian Johns, publicly acknowledged that the ABC had an internal shortfall and was in need of fundamental restructure.

Answers provided in estimates suggest something other than a national crisis for the national broadcaster. Firstly, it should be noted that some $6 million has been isolated as being saved in management and infrastructure without any impact on programming. A million dollars in savings is anticipated from reductions in non-program related travel and the purchase of office equipment. Five million dollars in savings are expected to be from management and administration costs.

BREAK.PARA: The ABC has stated that there will be no effect on rural, remote and regional communities as a result of a reduction in operating expenses. There will be no effect on children's programs or sporting programs. There will be no effect on entertainment programs. No news or current affairs programs will be removed. There will be no impact on the amount of Australian content on ABC radio. In areas where changes have been made, say, in terms of in-house documentaries and dramas, there will be no impact on documentaries, but the Radio National radio play The Box Seat will be discontinued and resources directed into the Sunday play.

Already much of the ABC's drama and documentary outputs are co-productions or made by independent producers. What is the magic then of the ABC producing this product itself if it can save costs and retain Australian content by commissioning or buying it from independents?

Local radio will have some changes with morning programs combined on metropolitan radio and regional stations accessing part of the program. There will be regional‐metropolitan links in early afternoons. Aside from Western Australia, there will be a national evening program. Victoria and South Australia will have state wide programs on Sunday mornings. There will be some changes in programming to Radio National, with certain programs being shortened or combined and incorporated with other similar programs, but these programs will not be taken off the air.

The ABC's unsuccessful and costly venture into pay TV was no myth. While efforts have been made to cut the losses incurred with free to air news and current affairs, this remains a singularly unsuccessful and costly venture. I can go on, but instead I would rather be positive. This government has recognised that, if the ABC is to meet the challenges ahead not only in terms of funding but also in terms of the technological transformation of the communication industry, it will need assistance to redefine and reposition itself for the fast approaching 21st century.

The Mansfield inquiry announced in July is charged with responsibility to review the future role and functions of the ABC and to report to the minister. At long last there is an opportunity for real reform of the ABC and for the targeting of services and activities in key areas. It has been 15 years since the Dix review, the last independent review of the ABC. Of course the broadcasting and communications environment has changed. It is a different landscape and the Mansfield inquiry is timely.

If it is to truly be `our ABC', action must match the rhetoric. The review is the first time in 15 years that the community—the real stakeholders in the future of the ABC—has been able to have a say on the roles and priorities of the ABC. If the ABC is truly to be for all of us and not just some of us, we should welcome this examination and embrace the outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Australian Democrats in this debate today to support the matter of public importance before the chamber which has been proposed by Senator Chris Schacht and which we endorse.

SPEECH.PARA: Sixty-four years ago Australia's only independent national broadcaster was born. It was committed, in the words of former Prime Minister Joseph Lyons, to `service all sections and to satisfy the diversified tastes of the public'. Obviously the ABC has evolved since then—I hesitate to say that it has `grown', because that would imply that it is, perhaps, a larger version of what it was 64 years ago. It has evolved. It has changed, diversified, embraced new technologies and evolved.

From its humble beginnings as a radio broadcaster it now consists of six Australia wide radio networks, nine metropolitan radio stations, 49 regional stations, Radio National, ABC Classic FM, the Parliamentary and News Network on radio, a national television service, Australia Television, six symphony orchestras, 24 ABC shops, over 110 ABC centres and an on‐line Internet service. It has done all of this only with guaranteed and adequate federal government funding.
The Liberal and National parties' election document Better Communications stated:

. . . this vast network provides a diverse range of programs and performances of cultural value and intellectual integrity. The ABC has a proud record of offering high quality and diverse programming across a broad spectrum of human interests including news, current affairs, drama, sport, and the arts.
Indeed it has. The Democrats endorse that statement wholeheartedly, and I am sure this view is supported and shared by the majority of Australians.

In fact in June this year an AGB McNair poll found that 61 per cent of respondents opted for the maintenance of government funding to the ABC at existing levels. Twenty‐four per cent declared that the funding should be increased. That is 85 per cent, a powerful majority, supporting the work of the ABC. The poll, incidentally, included regular ABC listeners as well as those Australians who do not listen to or do not avail themselves of the national broadcaster's services.

We must ask what has happened in the past few months to change the mind of the coalition government. Before the election, clearly the coalition strongly supported the ABC. Why, since then, has the coalition government opted to break the ABC's triennial funding arrangement when it said it would honour it? Why has the government suddenly decided that the ABC should contribute to budget reduction measures when the ABC was quarantined from the so-called efficiency dividend under its funding arrangement? Obviously this was merely election propaganda on behalf of the coalition parties—or should I say the cabinet, because it appears that the government does not have the full support of its own members on this issue.

We only have to look at the National Party conference which has opposed funding cuts to the ABC. The National Farmers Federation has opposed the ABC cuts. Even the Young Liberals have come out quite outspokenly and opposed the cuts to the ABC. Why have they done so?

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think anyone supports the cuts.

—I am looking too, Senator Lundy, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to find people who support the cuts. Clearly the polls show us that they do not. We cannot find members in the coalition ranks who support the cuts and certainly the other parties in this place do not support them.

SPEECH.PARA: Why don't people then support the cuts? Clearly because they know the damage that these cuts will have on the ABC and, most importantly, the damage that these cuts will have on rural, remote and local communities who rely on the ABC for information and entertainment as well as locally produced and relevant material.

We have come to believe that the ABC is protected by legislation—the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act of 1983. But is this act really enough to protect the ABC from the viciousness of successive governments intent on destroying the ABC through funding cuts after funding cuts? No, it is not. There are several reasons, but there are two specific reasons why this legislation appears to be no longer fully protective.

Firstly, in its charter, the ABC is required to `provide services which are comprehensive . . . of a high standard . . . which inform and which educate'. Politicians of all persuasions and other powerful groups are sometimes discomforted by the ABC's pursuit of their activities, perhaps even irritated by their independence. In fact, we heard Senator Schacht earlier refer to the fact that on occasions even our Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was a little less relaxed and was uncomfortable by the scrutiny that the ABC provides of his role and also that of other politicians and other parties.

But a broadcaster which seeks to inform the community of the disadvantage of a particular government policy, say, is not something that the government of that day wants to hear. The government would prefer that the community actually took what was served to them—that they listened to programs that fully supported and favoured their particular views.

But do we really want an ABC that is run with some kind of national totalitarian stance? Do we really want to be fed the views that are comfortable to governments and decision makers? Of course we do not, and I, for one, strongly dissent from that notion. Secondly, and to further guarantee that the legislation is not sufficient protection for the ABC, the government has now announced the Mansfield inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer), I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement on Australia's 1996 APEC individual action plan and to take note of the statement and a related document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

I table for the information of honourable senators, Australia's 1996 APEC Individual Action Plan (IAP) which will be presented, along with the IAPs of all other APEC members, at the APEC Ministerial and Leaders Meetings to be held in the coming days in the Philippines.

Under the Osaka Action Agenda agreed by APEC Leaders in 1995, all APEC members are required to prepare IAPs to show the steps they are taking to meet their trade and investment liberalisation commitments agreed at the Bogor APEC Leaders meeting in 1994.

The government is fully committed to the Osaka objectives consistent with the need for Australia to be actively associated, through APEC, with the move by the growing Asia‐Pacific economies to consolidate the liberalisation of the region and underpin its future prospects.

Members' IAPs are to conform to the general principles of the Osaka Action Agenda including comprehensiveness, WTO consistency, comparability, and transparency. Also, members are to address fifteen areas in their IAPs including the core liberalisation areas of tariffs, non‐tariff measures, services and investment.

The Osaka Action Agenda provides for the IAP process to be ongoing with members submitting revised IAPs on an annual basis assisted by a process of informal consultations and review among members. The 1996 IAPs to be submitted by APEC members later this month will therefore be the first step in a long‐term progressive process leading to the Bogor objective of free and open trade and investment in the Asia‐Pacific region by 2010 for industrialised economies and 2020 for developing economies. As such, they represent the start of the difficult process of translating the rhetoric from Bogor and Osaka into real and detailed commitments.

The plan that I am tabling today is the final version of Australia's 1996 IAP and will be taken through to the final stage of consultation at senior officials' and ministerial‐level at the APEC meetings in Manila over the coming weekend. honourable senators may recall that I announced in May that Australia had submitted a draft form of the IAP. All other members also submitted drafts in May and the process of consultation and review has been underway throughout the year.
The government has had wide ranging consultations with Australian industry, as well as the state and territory governments, on the development of Australia's IAP.

The Australian IAP reflects the fact that the Australian economy has been moving down a liberalising path and is well placed to conform with the guidelines for the preparation of IAPs as agreed by Leaders in Osaka. It also reflects the expectation by all economies that the IAPs will, understandably, contain more detail on the near‐term liberalisation than on the longer‐term, and that economies will be undertaking their own assessment of comparability as the IAP process evolves.

On tariffs, the Australian IAP includes the existing tariff reduction programs to the year 2000 in the textiles, clothing and footwear and passenger motor vehicles sectors but does not pre‐judge the outcome of the reviews of tariff levels beyond 2000 in those sectors. The IAP also reflects the fact that Australia's general tariff has been phased down to a level of no higher than 5 per cent. It includes a commitment to review 0‐5 per cent tariffs by 2000 or earlier subject to an assessment of progress in the liberalisation commitments by others in APEC and the WTO.

The IAP also includes previously‐announced policy directions on micro‐economic reform in the services sectors. For example, the introduction of full and open competition from 1 July 1997 in the telecommunications sector, the winding back of maritime coastal protection by 2000, and the progressive liberalisation of access to the Australian aviation market. Under competition policy, the IAP refers to the review of exemptions to the competitive conduct rules that will commence in 1997‐98.

Other measures addressed in the IAP include investment and important trade facilitation issues such as standards and customs procedures, intellectual property rights, competition policy, deregulation. On business mobility, Australia is working with its APEC partners to develop the APEC Business Travel Card to allow the equivalent of visa‐free travel for eligible business persons.

Consistent with the comparability element of IAPs, Australia will be seeking, through the IAP process, to use the liberalisation of the Australian economy to argue for enhanced market access of interest to Australian exporters in other APEC economies. The government has used all opportunities for ministerial and official‐level contact with our APEC partners to urge improvements in their IAPs. We have stressed Australian market access priorities as determined in consultation with Australian industry. We have also encouraged the Philippines, as chair of APEC in 1996, to exercise its leadership role in urging members generally to improve their IAPs.

As for 1996, I expect modest outcomes as this year is only the beginning of the process. But we have set the platform to pursue Australia's interests as IAPs are reviewed and modified in the coming years.

There has been a gradual improvement in the quality of IAPs during the year. I expect that the 1996 IAPs will represent a modest improvement in access for Australian exporters and will illustrate the wide range of liberalisation under way in the region. Importantly, the IAPs will signal a commitment by APEC members to continue further opening of their economies. The tabling of IAPs in final form at the time of the forthcoming APEC Ministerial and Leaders meetings will be an opportunity for a more detailed assessment.

The results for 1996 are broadly in line with realistic expectations at the beginning of what is a sustained process which will go out to 2010 and beyond. APEC has made a reasonable start and has helped to reinforce an overall trend towards liberalisation in the region, although there are sectors of export interest to Australia which remain to be addressed.
The government will report further on the IAPs in the context of reporting on the outcome of the ministerial and Leaders Meetings.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Report which I have just tabled deals with a proposal to increase the scientific research capacity of the CSIRO in Canberra by constructing improved facilities for high quality biological research within the Division of Plant Industry.

The proposal involves the demolition of existing laboratory facilities, which are seriously substandard and outdated, and to redevelop the site to construct a new research laboratory, which will be integrated with a CSIRO Research Interaction Centre. The Interaction Centre will offer the opportunity for members of the community to view and take part in interactive exhibits illustrating CSIRO research and its applications.

In its examination of the proposal, the Committee found that existing CSIRO research facilities for biomolecular research at Black Mountain are inadequate, dispersed, overcrowded and do not meet contemporary occupational health and safety standards. Therefore, there is a need to provide modern research facilities for biomolecular research to enable the Division of Plant Industry to continue research programs aimed at enhancing Australia's multi-billion dollar agribusinesses.

The integration of the Research Interaction Centre will provide opportunities for the CSIRO to display publicly the results of research being undertaken by all Divisions and heighten the profile of the organisation and the scientists who make a major contribution to Australia's scientific research efforts.

The Committee further concluded that the location of the proposed complex makes good use of space available within the Division of Plant Industry precinct and that the design concept integrates the proposed laboratory, Research Interaction Centre, conference facilities and staff amenities in a functional manner.

In the public consultation process, as attested by evidence received by the Committee, the CSIRO proposal has strong support from organisations and individuals with an interest in fostering public knowledge of CSIRO achievements in science. According to market research, it is estimated that the Research Interaction Centre should attract in excess of 100,000 visitors annually.
Based on admission charges, the Centre will be self-funding.
