DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK ZONING PLANS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 November, on motion by Senator Lees:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Cairns Section Zoning Plan (Amendment No. 1 of 1996), the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Central Section Zoning Plan (Amendment No. 1 of 1996) and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Mackay/Capricorn Section Zoning Plan (Amendment No. 1 of 1996), made under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to sum up this debate, and I will be brief. I do want to go back to the two baskets of reasons, if you like, of why we should today be voting down this change in zoning. What the government is proposing to do is to rezone part of the four per cent of the reef that is now protected from `protected' to `fishing‐experimental'.

SPEECH.PARA: The first of the baskets involves process. There is a whole range of issues relating to the processes that the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) did not follow—what he should have done before he brought these changes before this place. Indeed, in one case there are processes that GBRMPA itself has not followed. The second basket of reasons includes the substantive ones, the environmental reasons of why we simply should not be tampering and should not be opening up what little of our Great Barrier Reef is protected.

I want to look first at the processes. There has not been an environmental impact assessment on this project, despite the fact that this is a Commonwealth action that will definitely have an impact on the environment. We argue that it will have a very significant impact on the environment.

Secondly, the minister did not designate the proposal under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act before he tabled these rezonings in parliament. Again, I stress this was a requirement because it will have an impact on the environment.

Thirdly, the minister did not ask for advice from the Australian Heritage Commission under the Australian Heritage Commission Act, as he was required to do. Clearly this is an area on the register of the national estate and, before he tabled the rezonings, this advice should have been sought.

The primary aim, if we look at the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act, is to protect the reef; it is not to talk about a variety of uses. We argue very strongly that what we are seeing here is nothing to do with the protection of the reef. Of course, within that act we have the precautionary principle. No matter which way the minister likes to define `precautionary', it has nothing do with fishing out endangered species to see the rate of fishing that this area can sustain and how many fish come back. The precautionary principle is about arguing that, if there is going to be any sort of risk, we say no. It is not precautionary to open up areas that are now protected and kill the marine life in them in the name of experimental science.

Then we have the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. This means the area should be conserved, protected and transmitted to future generations. Surely the spirit of this act is not being met by these proposals before us today.

Before making decisions on rezoning protected areas and placing those rezonings before parliament, all of the previous measures should have been done. Even if some of these processes can be set in train now, it is too late. We also need this information before we make this decision here today. If we disallow today, the minister can go away, follow the correct procedures, go through the processes and then bring this back before us in good time when we, too, have that information before us.

The last process I will mention very briefly is one that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority itself is actually looking at. That is, after some previous experiments—in particular the ANCA damage experiment, which got so much bad publicity and raised so many concerns it was eventually stopped—the authority has set up within its own ranks what has been described to me by one person as an ethics committee. It is a committee that is going to look at whether or not experiments really should be done. This proposal has apparently not even been passed by that internal committee.

Then we have the substantive issues. There has been a wide range of experiments already done on the reef. There has been a variety of fishing experiments done in quite damaging ways. They do no longer, I am assured, dynamite sections of the reef. The last one that I can find documented was in 1991, but they certainly were doing that. The effect of that is that it ruptures the bladders of the fish and kills them. They then float to the surface and can be counted. Then the scientists can monitor what fish return to those areas of the reef.

Then there is rotenone poisoning, which I am assured is still going on in places. In those experiments large clouds of this material are put into the water and they spread. Apparently very quick fish, such as some of the shark species, can get away. The others do not. They drown. They cannot breathe through this material. They float to the surface. They can then be counted. The rate of return of a variety of species can then be measured.

There have been trawling experiments already on the reef—ones where 39 square kilometre areas were trawled in protected areas of the reef several years ago. They were very similar experiments to those proposed now. I point out to the minister that, even though we are talking now about rezoning for line fishing, if he reads through the methodology the scientists are proposing, in time it will open up to further trawling experiments under these very regulations we have before us today.

Other experiments which have been looking at behaviour of marine organisms have included smashing coral to see whether fish come and feed on smashed coral, and bleaching live coral to look at the impact of that. There are experiments planned—and apparently they have started around Mackay—that involve pouring oil on pristine mangrove areas. There are other experiments involving pouring nutrients and phosphates on corals. Of course, there is the one I have already mentioned—the anchor damage experiment. Rather than looking at anchor damage that had already occurred on the reef, they were actually going out and proposing that they damage pristine reefs to see what was going to happen from anchor damage in the long term.

I am going through these not to suggest that I oppose all forms of experimentation. We certainly do not. As a former science teacher and one who has had some training in this area, I am not for a moment suggesting that we should move away and stop all scientific experiment—in fact, I have one daughter who has just completed an honours degree in biotechnology—but we are talking about protected areas of the reef and what very little part of the reef remains protected. We have 96 per cent of the reef—not that I suggest for a moment we should be pouring oil on it or dynamiting it—that we could be using for some of these line fishing experiments and experiments that involve, for example, tagging and releasing fish to look at their movements.

I stress here again, Minister, that despite some of the spin that has been put on this, we are not talking about a one‐year opening; we are talking about five years of various experiments on protected areas. As I said at the beginning of my speech, there is a need to bring this home to Australians—particularly those who have campaigned for so many years on forest issues. They were campaigning to protect 10 to 15 per cent of forests. Here we have only four per cent of the reef protected, and we are fighting to hang on to that. Surely this government should talking about actually improving the percentage of the reef that is now protected and increasing that percentage to a far more realistic area.

I would argue that once you set the precedent for opening up protected areas, you are getting onto very shaky ground. Where do we stop? Unfortunately, although we have quite a number of scientists who are arguing very clearly that we should not be doing this, they would be putting their careers at risk if they spoke out from within some of these organisations. I think that the whole idea of use is one that is very different from the idea of protection. Hopefully senators will vote today to protect what little remains closed off from fishermen on the Great Barrier Reef. I commend this motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on this matter, having already spoken in the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and I thank the Senate. The minister might also seek leave. I am not sure about that but, if he does, it is appropriate that I make this brief contribution before he does.

SPEECH.PARA: During the debate on these regulations on 6 November, the opposition indicated that its support for the regulations was conditional on the fishing experiment being independently assessed by the Australian Heritage Commission and evaluated under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act; and also Senator Hill assuring the Senate that if the AHC or the EPA advise him that this experiment is to any extent environmentally unsound or inadvisable, he will accept the advice and not proceed. I can indicate to the Senate that today the minister has indicated that Dr McPhail has formally referred the experiment to the AHC and the EPA.

PARA.BREAK: I think it is unfortunate that it was not until concerns about the process were raised in the chamber that the experiment was formally referred to the specialist agencies, as is required under the Australian Heritage Com mission Act and the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. I say once again that I believe that the minister has got the process back to front. These regulations should not have been tabled in the Senate until the AHC and the EPA had provided their advice on the impact of the experiment on the world heritage area, and until that advice had been properly considered. The belated referral means that senators will not have the opportunity to assess the merits of the experiment in light of the AHC and the EPA advice.

SPEECH.PARA: In the absence of this advice, the opposition continues to insist on the commitment that I sought from Senator Hill on behalf of the shadow environment minister, Dr Lawrence. I say with the best spirit I am able to muster in this circumstance that Senator Hill does not have a strong record on taking the advice of his specialist agencies on developments which impact on world heritage areas. The minister's recent decision to grant consent approvals for the Port Hinchinbrook resort development is a case in point. That decision indicates Senator Hill's propensity for ignoring the AHC's concerns about the environmental impact of developments on a world heritage area if that advice is not to his liking.

A commitment by Senator Hill in this chamber is the outstanding issue, in the view of the opposition, in this matter. Opening up world heritage protected areas, especially considering the minister's poor regard for the proper statutory process, is a serious matter. The opposition therefore could not support these regulations without the minister's assurance to the Senate that if the AHC or the EPA advise him that the experiment is to any extent environmentally unsound or inadvisable, he will accept that advice and not proceed. I say to Senator Hill that I do hope he is willing to give that level of assurance to the Senate. If he does, then that obviously would mean that the opposition would oppose this disallowance motion. But in the absence of that level of assurance, we would be supporting the motion that stands in Senator Lees's name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave— This is really a development from the last time we debated this matter. As is now clear, I think, the opposition sought from the government a number of things. The request was in two parts. The first part of the request was that it sought that there be a designation under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act for the experiment. It similarly sought that the advice of the Australian Heritage Commission be formally required.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the request was a number of specifics: it wanted explicit monitoring mechanisms to be in place; it wanted a commitment from the government to develop a proper management strategy for commercial and recreational fishing; it wanted a guarantee that the reef will be rezoned back to its current status; and it wanted an assurance from me, as Minister for the Environment, that I would report to the parliament at the end of the first year of the experiment to inform the parliament of the preliminary results of fishing on the green reefs.

Each of the four second-tier requirements was met positively in a response that I gave before the last debate. As I read it, Senator Faulkner, in his contribution to that debate, on behalf of Dr Lawrence acknowledged that I had given assurances to each of those. So they have been met in the terms that the opposition has requested.

As to the first two requests—a formal designation under the EP(IP) Act and a formal reference to the AHC—the statutory authority, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, has carried out both those requests, as has been acknowledged by Senator Faulkner. As requested by Dr Lawrence, the shadow spokesperson, I have sent to her a copy of the letters from Dr McPhail under the EP(IP) Act and under the AHC Act, together with the somewhat voluminous attachments. I will table a set of those documents here now so it can be seen that the full requests of the opposition, as set out in the letter from Dr Lawrence dated 15 November 1996 to me, have been met. I table a copy of the letter from Dr Lawrence as well.

Senator Faulkner, however, in his speech of 6 November added a further requirement to that which Dr Lawrence had put in her letter to me—that is, I would be required to assure the Senate that, if the AHC or the EPA advise me that this experiment is environmentally unsound or inadvisable, I will accept that advice and not proceed.

I would suggest that Senator Faulkner has got it wrong in relation to process for the second time. He first got it wrong in his determination as to what was the correct timetable for seeking a designation under the EP(IP) Act and under the AHC Act. As is stated, it is not at the time of seeking this regulation, this new zoning plan, in the Senate that these acts are triggered; it is when the authority, if it decides to, goes to the next step, which is to designate special management provisions in order to allow the experiment to proceed, that these two acts are triggered and the authority should so act.

But Dr McPhail, the chairman, has said that, because of the requirement of the opposition in this matter, he is not waiting to see whether the zoning plans stand the assessment of this parliament. He nevertheless has taken the second step now before the time in which he was required to do so, which, on our legal advice, would be the proper time for him to do so. That is in accordance with the request of the opposition to try to meet their requirements, notwithstanding the technical deficiency.

The second process error is that, despite the fact that it is Dr McPhail, the authority, that has referred the matters—it is a separate statutory authority, it is designated, it must address the response under the EPIP Act, and it must address the response under the AHC Act—Senator Faulkner has nevertheless, in the additional requirement that he put down in the Senate, required me to act upon their advice. I am saying that he has got it wrong. It is up to Dr McPhail as a separate statutory authority to consider the advice and, under the terms of each of those pieces of legislation, decide how to act. It is not for me to consider at all.

Even if this was a designation involving me, I would have had trouble in accepting what you say, Senator Faulkner. It would be improper for me to bind myself in advance to advice that I have not received when the obligation under the act, loosely expressed, is that I am obliged to take into account their advice. I am not obliged. It would be an abdication of my responsibility to the AHC and to EP(IP) to accept the stricture that the opposition is seeking to place upon me. That is something that I am sure Senator Faulkner would never have accepted. If he did, I would have condemned him for abdicating his statutory responsibility.

What I am obliged to do, and what Senator Faulkner was obviously obliged to do when he was minister, is to ensure that the proper statutory process is followed and, clearly, that the advice of these authorities is properly taken into account. In the end it is upon my head that the decision has to be made. I have to withstand the consequences of that. Otherwise the statute would have been differently drawn, and there would not have been a role for the minister to make an assessment and to offer advice to the designated minister, which is the usual process, to make recommendations on the basis of taking into account the advice of EP(IP), the advice of the EPA in that instance, or the advice of the AHC.

So, as a matter of process, firstly it is irrelevant what Senator Faulkner is seeking of me because it is up to Dr McPhail's separate statutory authority to take that advice. Secondly, even if it was my charge, then what he is asking me to do is to go beyond that which is my statutory requirement, which would be quite wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just use your power as a minister.
—What you are not facing up to is that this is a referral by a separate statutory authority. It gets the advice, and it determines how to act in response to that.

SPEECH.PARA: At question time you said that you would be interested in our assessment of my legal position. I have sought some advice at very short notice, which this advice acknowledges, from the Attorney-General's Department. They say:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The zoning plans as amended would empower the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, not the minister, to designate the application of a special management provision to a fisheries experimental error. My preliminary advice is that it is doubtful that the minister has power in accordance with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act to direct the authority as to how to exercise that function.

Now is not the time to revisit the debate as to whether we should take the advice of the scientists or risk the consequences of not taking that advice. That was the debate of the other day. What we have nevertheless sought to do is meet all reasonable requests by the opposition in this matter, which we say we have done as far as we are able.

SPEECH.PARA: All the assurances that Dr Lawrence was wanting in relation to monitoring, rezoning and ensuring that a management plan has been put in place have been complied with. The requirement that it go for assessment under the EPIP Act and the requirement that it go to the AHC for assessment has been accepted. The only requirement that we cannot meet is the requirement that Senator Faulkner added in the last debate. We cannot meet that because it is irrelevant. It is not my responsibility; it is the responsibility of Dr McPhail.

If it were my responsibility, I would meet all my statutory responsibilities, and I would properly take into account the advice of the AHC and the advice of any environmental assessment under the EPIP Act. Obviously, I listen to the advice of specialists, because it would be foolish to do otherwise. I not only listen to it but also find the advice of the specialist groups very helpful to me in meeting my statutory responsibility. But that is as far as it would be proper for me to go.

BROWN AMENDMENTS:

The key point which I have pointed out to Senator Brown of the Tasmanian Greens which is abundantly clear on any ordinary reading of the legislation is that the bill will not pick up the protest action he is talking about. This Tasmanian Green amendment and debate is not about facts or about legitimate concerns. It is about scare mongering on the part of Senator Brown.

The two most common forms of protest engaged in by human rights, consumer and environmental groups are consumer boycotts and picketing. Consumer boycotts are expressly excluded from the operation of the Trade Practices Act by section 51 (2A). And pickets have been upheld again and again by the Courts as a valid and legal form of protest. The Federal Court in the 1993 J-Corp case held that peaceful picketing was not a secondary boycott. This is because the purpose of the picket was not to hinder and prevent trade, but to provide information. The English Courts have adopted a similar view, with the 1993 Court of Appeal decision in Middlebrook Mushrooms v TGWU finding that unions targeting consumers of a supermarket in protest against the industrial policies of the supermarket uphold that the principal of freedom of speech was very important, and that this was not action targeted at the management.

The High Court, in the famous Theophanus case has found an implied right to freedom of speech in the Australian Constitution. The likelihood of any Australian Court ignoring the High Court and the growing line of English cases finding civil rights more important than commercial rights is simply remote in the extreme.
Senator Brown of the Tasmanian Greens is simply incorrect.

The second part of Senator Brown's motion seeks to broaden the exclusion to cover industrial action. In doing so, he is seeking to ask a Coalition Government to provide added protection to union industrial action that the previous Labor Government was not prepared to provide. This is political naivete in the extreme.

The difficulty with this approach is that it will encourage unions to dress up inappropriate disputes about other issues as environmental or consumer or human rights issues. The unions could claim that the right to strike itself is a human right (although this is not 100 per cent clear in international law), giving a total protection to industrial action. As such, Senator Brown's amendment is poorly drafted and would allow unions to engage in a wide range of totally inappropriate actions against which the public should be protected.

This bill will not render illegal any secondary boycott conduct by unions which is currently legal. The Democrats do not agree that the extreme legal restrictions on the right to take industrial action in this country are appropriate. But, we deal with the fact that neither the Labor Government nor the Coalition Government have been prepared to change that situation. Our objective in redrafting these provisions was to ensure that primary boycotts, are, by and large, dealt with in the AIRC, and that there are protection and defences for certain categories of secondary boycotts. Those objectives have been achieved, and we believe that Senator Brown's amendment is simply unnecessary in all the circumstances.

OPPOSITION AMENDMENTS:
"SHIPS OF SHAME"
I am again astounded by the hypocrisy of the Opposition in moving this amendment.

Let me start by re-stating the current law. Under section 162 of the Industrial Relations Act introduced by the ALP in 1993, a secondary boycott by the Maritime Union in defence of seafarers on a ship in an Australian port is illegal. Following the conciliation period, the MUA and its members are subject to injunctions and damages. That is Labor's law.
So, the ALP is asking this Senate and a Coalition Government to provide protection for industrial action which they were not prepared to provide in 13 years of Government. What hypocrisy.

Let's not hear any heart rending speeches from Labor about standards of international shipping. If Labor was so concerned about it, why didn't it ratify ILO Convention 147 which sets minimum conditions for international sea farers? The 1976 convention was under consideration by the previous Government for 13 years.

Why was the performance of the previous Government the subject of critical reports on ships of shame issues by the Government's own members on the House of Representatives Transport Committee, headed by former Transport Minister Laurie Brereton?

Your record follows you like a bad odour Senator Sherry, so don't lecture me about workers rights. There is nothing more despicable, nothing more hypocritical and nothing more damaging to public faith in the body politic than the ALP's shameless mouthing of pro-worker platitudes which were and which are the exact opposite of their policy pronouncements.

I think the hypocrisy of the ALP and the misinformed comments of Senator Brown of the Tasmanian Greens, can be contrasted with the genuine concern of other politicians, and I wish to note the long advocacy by Senator Margetts of better shipping practices here. I share Senator Margetts concern for shipping practices in Australian waters. But, I do not believe that this is the appropriate bill to deal with these issues.

I also wish to note for the record the enormous effort that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority has made in the past five years to improve its port control inspections of foreign flagged ships coming into Australian ports. 60 per cent of ships are not inspected, some 2700 inspections last year, with 250 ships detained until health and safety standards are met. AMSA has recently increased funding for these activities, and the Democrats welcome that. But, there are gaps in AMSA's coverage. While I am satisfied that port inspections are adequate to deal with the physical environment on ships, AMSA's mandate on conditions of employment and human rights are much less clear.

Over the past two weeks, I have been discussing the issues associated with ships of shame with the office of Transport Minister John Sharp. The Coalition's pre-election policy commits it to the highest standards of safety for ships entering Australian waters. We intend holding them to that. Minister Sharp has confirmed that the Government's response to the House "Ships of Shame" Committee report will be tabled in this session. We have been further assured that the response will be positive and comprehensive, and recognise and believe the genuine commitment of this Government to action on these issues.

The Democrats recognise this is a new Government, and that the Government has made strong statements that it will not cop sub‐standard shipping in our ports. We are prepared to give the Government this one opportunity to get its policy settings right. Before the Government can present to this parliament any proposals to open up Australian shipping to more access by foreign flagged ships, or to introduce a second register allowing for foreign nationals on Australian flagged ships, it must ensure that there is a genuine level playing field. It must ensure that Australian seafarers will not be forced to compete against sub-standard sweat shop conditions. I flag now that the Democrats will look for the Government to fulfil its obligations and undertakings in shipping reform legislation brought by the Government in its response on the "ships of shame" report and the ratification of ILO 147 is not adequate.

Coming back to the ALP's hypocrisy of seeking to provide legal protection for action that is illegal under their laws, we will oppose this amendment at this stage. As I said earlier, there are protections built into the legislation for carefully targeted actions by the MUA.

I wish to draw particular attention to the object of the Trade Practices Act in section 2 which states that the object is to enhance the welfare of Australia through the promotion of competition and fair trading. In relation to shipping, it is clearly not fair trading, fair competition, if a foreign participant is seeking to undercut internationally recognised conditions and standards. That is not fair trading. A Court in deciding whether to grant relief would obviously have to have regard to whether the granting of relief furthered this object and I would believe that the MUA could argue successfully that an injunction should not be granted if it would encourage unfair trading in respect of shipping.

New section 87AA requires the Court to have regard to whether the applicant has or could have commenced conciliation proceedings in the Commission first. Section 51(2) also requires a Court to disregard any act done in relation to a contract or understanding on remuneration, conditions of employment, hours of work or working conditions. The combined effects of these two sections make it fairly clear that industrial issues should be dealt with primarily by the AIRC if they are genuine industrial issues. Obviously, the Court should have regard to the importance of allowing the AIRC to fulfil its statutory obligations, in particular object 3(k) which refers to assisting in giving effect to Australia's international obligations in relation to labour standards. Given shipping issues are subject to the regulation by both the ILO and the International Maritime Organisation, the importance of allowing the AIRC to do its job is doubly important.

It is further open to the MUA to seek authorisation under section 88 of the Trade Practices Act for carefully targeted action acting as the agent for the International Transport Federation, to defend the industrial interests of members of that Federation. Given the importance of the issues I have outlined, I believe that the ACCC would be very sympathetic to such an application.

If the ACCC declined an application, if the Courts were reluctant to give the Trade Practices and Industrial Relations Acts the natural meanings I have outlined and if the Government fall short on its "ships of shame" policy response, then the Democrats may revisit this issue. We do not regard it as a closed book. But, we believe that at this point of the political and legal cycle, the amendment being moved by the ALP is inappropriate.
SCHEDULE 18
OPPOS 340, GREEN 80
The Democrats will oppose this amendment to delete the schedule. In doing so, I wish to expand a little on our general reasons for doing so.

The pre-1993 Trade Practices Act provision in section 45D were extremely harsh provisions They picked up not just secondary boycotts, but a wide range of primary boycotts as well due to the sloppy drafting of the provisions. Professor Breen Creighton of Latrobe University conducted an analysis of the 200 applications made between 1977 and 1993, and found that about two thirds of them were in relation to primary boycotts, capable of being contrived into the provision. Section 45D became a symbol of employer power over unions. The reality was a little different. There was never a pecuniary fine ever taken under the provisions. There were never damages ever collected under the provisions. There were only 6 ex parte injunctions ever granted. The total number of injunctions granted was about 50 of those 200 cases.

The provisions were threatened only once against an environment organisation. It had never been used against a consumer boycott of any sort, and had not been successful against other protest action such as picketing.

The new 45D will be much narrower in scope than the old. In other words it is far less draconian. It will not apply to primary boycotts, with the narrow exception of movement of goods in and out of Australia. So, that means we are talking about only a third of the cases actioned under the old Labor act's provision. It will not apply to environmental or consumer boycotts. It will require the court to have regard to whether the applicant has or could have conciliated the dispute in the Commission. The explanatory memorandum will encourage a broader interpretation of the exclusions on employment related matters. And, on top of that the new Trade Practices Act has an objects clause referring to the importance of promoting competition and fair trading and consumer protection. So, it is a very different legal environment in which it would operate.

The Democrats went to the last election opposed to the re-instatement of the old 45D and 45E. And, we have kept to this promise. The provisions we will vote for today are much, much narrower in scope. They target expressly the cases of boycott activity which Labor, the Coalition and the Democrats have consistently regarded as undesirable—that is, boycotts where an innocent third party is involved in a dispute between two other parties. The law in this country, and the law in many other countries have always precluded such boycotts as an undesirable and unsanctioned form of industrial action.

Indeed, Labor's laws which they are seeking to re-instate still make such boycotts illegal. It is difficult to conceive of any secondary boycotts, particularly boycotts involving industrial action, which were legal under Labor, but made illegal under this bill. The scope of the provisions is very similar.

The difference is only in relation to the compulsory conciliation period. The 1993 amendment to the I.R. Act, supported by the Democrats, included a compulsory conciliation period of up to 72 hours before an employer could seek an injunction. In many cases, this worked very well. But, in too many cases, the length of the period was a nega tive. Employers who had no economic resistance to delays, in building, in perishable goods in particular, in just‐in‐time and peak period manufacturing situations capitulated to union demands as they were unable to sustain the damage.

The provisions we are supporting retain the linkage of both commercial and industrial issues. New section 87AA will require the Court to have regard to whether the applicant has or could have commenced proceedings in the Commission, particular conciliation. Obviously, if the Court believes that there is scope for settlement of the matters underlying the dispute, then it has an absolute discretion to refuse relief.

But, by placing this in the Court's hand, the Court can balance these considerations against the likelihood of real and unsustainable economic loss, something which the Commission has not taken sufficient account of.

In short, in supporting these amendments, we are responding to the developments in industrial practice since the 1993 amendments. For Labor to say that the 1993 amendments were working perfectly would be to ignore reality. For the Coalition to say that the pre-1993 45D and E were working perfectly and fairly would also be to ignore reality. The amended provisions we support learn from both experiences, and incorporate the best of both sets of provisions. It demonstrates the continuing responsibility of the Democrats in seeking to ensure that industrial and commercial laws are contemporary, fair, balanced and workable.
SCHEDULE 18:
OPPOSITION AMDTS 341-345

The Democrats are opposed to these amendments. Amendment 341 is basically unnecessary because of the harmonisation of State and Federal trade practices law occurring as a result of the competition policy reform agreements, as reflected by the National Competition Code.

Amendment 342 is a classic ALP try-on. From the safety of the moral high ground of Opposition the ALP is attempting to do something it refused to do in 13 years of Government, cap damages under secondary boycott provisions. If the ALP deemed these provisions were unnecessary in 1993—even though they were then in the UK legislation—then why are they needed now? In 1993, there had never been damages collected under boycott provisions in 16 years of litigation. The only difference is that in 1996, there now have never been damages collected in 19 years of litigation. As I said in speaking to the last ALP amendment, we believe there are a wide range of protections built into these provisions as they stand.

Amendment 343 seeks to restrict access to ex parte and interim injunctions. I think in practice the provision is flawed. A rogue union official could easily avoid an injunction by simply avoiding being served with the notice. Paragraph (b) restates the equitable principles already governing the granting of injunctions. These requirements are basically those already applied by the Courts, which require very strong evidence that immediate and irreparable damage will be done before breaching the basic tenet of equity that both parties deserve a hearing. These basic principles have been outlined in High Court Cases such as the 1912 case of Thomas Edison v Bullock and the 1977 case of Heatley v Tasmanian Racing and Gaming Commission.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What measures are in place to ensure that none of Australia's fisheries suffers a crash of the kind that affected the North Atlantic cod fishery.
(2) Is it a fact that the prawn fishery in the Gulf of Carpentaria and elsewhere result in an annual loss of 80,000 tonnes of marine life discarded as bycatch for 20,000 tonnes of prawns caught.

(3) What action has been taken to reduce the bycatch in the prawn fishery; specifically what reduction is likely as a result of Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) research into the modification of prawn-trawling nets.

(4) Has the CSIRO expressed concern that the number of boats is excessive in any Australian fishery; if so, in which fisheries is this the case and what action has been taken to reduce the number of boats.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Responsibility for the management of fisheries in Australia is shared between the Commonwealth, States and Territories.

The Constitution provides that the Commonwealth is responsible for the management of fisheries outside the 3 nautical mile territorial sea with States and internal Territories being responsible for fisheries in all other waters adjacent to that State.

The Offshore Constitutional Settlement (OCS) which came into force in the early 1980's, allows the Commonwealth and States to enter into arrangements that change fisheries jurisdictions. In particular, the Commonwealth and States may agree that either Commonwealth or State/Territory laws apply throughout a fishery from the low water mark to the outer limit of the Australian fishing zone (AFZ). Many major Australian fisheries are now managed under a single jurisdiction as a result of OCS arrangements agreed between specific States and the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth government is aware of the collapse that occurred in the North Atlantic Cod Fishery and aware of the variety of threats to fish stocks. Pressure on fish resources can come from a number of sources including commercial and recreational fishing, environmental pressures such as habitat changes, water pollution and runoff of pesticides, drought affected stream flows and natural fluctuations in fish populations.

The Australian Fisheries Management Authority (AFMA) was established in 1992 to manage Commonwealth fisheries. AFMA's objectives include ensuring that the exploitation of fisheries resources and the undertaking of any related activities are conducted in a manner consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development, and ensuring, through proper conservation and management measures, that the living resources of the AFZ are not endangered by over-exploitation. Management measures used by AFMA include restrictions on the number of boats licensed to fish, restrictions on fishing gear, seasonal and area closures and, in some cases, quotas on the amount of fish that can be caught.

In developing management arrangements, AFMA, through its Management Advisory Committees (MACs) and Consultative Committees (CCs), involves the fishing industry and more recently recreational fishing and nature conservation groups in the decision making process. AFMA also works with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) including the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) and the Bureau of Resource Sciences (BRS). AFMA also consults with other organisations such as the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation (FRDC), the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and the Department of Environment, Sport and Territories (DEST). Consultation also takes place between the Commonwealth and State fisheries agencies through the Ministerial Council and its Standing Committee on Fisheries and Aquaculture.

Good stock assessments are fundamental to effective fisheries management. To support the sustainable management of fisheries resources, AFMA has established and funded Fishery Assessment Groups (FAGs) which synthesise biological, ecosystem and economic information on Commonwealth fisheries to provide advice to AFMA.

The Fisheries Assessment Groups which include scientists from BRS and CSIRO co-ordinate, evaluate and regularly undertake assessment activity in each fishery. MACs and CCs also play a pivotal role in planning future direction of research through the development of five year Strategic Research Plans for each major fishery. The AFMA Board co-ordinates and manages the overall research strategy for Commonwealth fisheries through its Research and Environment Committee, which also acts as the Fisheries Research Advisory Board (FRAB) to the FRDC.
Advice from the FAGs, FRDC, CSIRO and other research providers is then used by AFMA to manage its fisheries.

Commonwealth fisheries are managed under a combination of limited entry and other input or output controls. Such management aims to maintain catches at a sustainable level in line with the objectives of the Fisheries Management Act 1991. One possible influence on the collapse of the North Atlantic cod was the unregulated fishing of this species on the high seas. Australia is a member of the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (SBT) (which was established to protect the highly migratory SBT). In addition, Australia is a signatory and strong supporter of the United Nations agreement on straddling fish stocks and highly migratory fish stocks.
Participation in international fora helps to conserve fish stocks harvested by Australians through effective international fisheries management.
I am confident that AFMA's management arrangements combined with targeted research will minimise the risk of collapse such as seen with cod in the North Atlantic.

(2) No, although high the loss of marine life varies from year to year. Prawn trawling usually results in a high proportion of the catch as bycatch, but bycatch from individual fisheries will vary depending on their location and the amount of fishing effort. Exact quantities of bycatch from Australian prawn fisheries are not known. In the prawn fisheries world bycatch levels are estimated to be somewhere between a ratio of 5:1 and 10:1 of bycatch to prawns.
The CSIRO has advised that in the Northern Prawn Fishery, with an average annual catch of 8,000 tonnes of prawns, the bycatch is in the order of 60,000 tonnes, i.e. a bycatch ratio of 7.5 : 1.

Some of the bycatch is of commercial value and retained for sale. I am advised by the CSIRO that fish in this bycatch is usually dead but other components such as crabs have a high survival rate. Discarded bycatch is returned overboard and continues to contribute to the food chain in the marine environment.

A $2 million program to encourage the voluntary use of bycatch reduction devices (BRDs) including turtle excluder devices (TEDs) commenced in July 1996. The program incorporates a `gear library' of BRDs that the fishing industry may borrow to trial. The gear library includes the AusTED and a range of overseas TED designs that were trialled and refined in the Gulf of Carpentaria study. The gear library will allow these devices to be trialled under commercial fishing conditions and their performance will be documented by a research observer. The program will also include workshops held at different ports, and a range of educational materials such as videos and newsletters to carry the message. It will be available to trawler operators in the Queensland east coast otter trawl fishery, the northern prawn fishery and the Torres Strait fishery. The program is run jointly by the Queensland Department of Primary Industry (QDPI), the Australian Maritime College (AMC) and the CSIRO. It is funded by the FRDC.
(3) The CSIRO has undertaken extensive research into issues and options to reduce bycatch in the prawn fishery.

The focus of initial research by the CSIRO, the Australian Maritime College and the Northern Territory government has been to develop trawl net modifications which eliminate the catch of large animals such as turtles. At the same time, reductions of around 30% in fish bycatch have been achieved. Fishing industry trials using a number of the most promising devices are currently in progress, such as Nordmore grids. The CSIRO has ongoing studies to further reduce fish bycatch.

(4) The CSIRO has advised that fisheries issues tend to be expressed in terms of the sustainability of catch level, rather than in terms of effort levels (for example, boat numbers) in a fishery. The CSIRO has provided advice in relation to capacity within the Northern Prawn Fishery. This advice has contributed to a reduction of the fishing fleet in recent years from 250 to 130 boats.
In the Orange Roughy Fishery, catches have been reduced from in excess of 40,000 tonnes per year to about 5,000 tonnes, principally on the basis of CSIRO stock assessments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Senator Margetts

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, upon notice, on 17 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the release on 17 October 1996 by Energy Resources of Australia of its Environ mental Impact Statement (EIS) with respect to the proposed Jabiluka uranium mine:

(1)(a) Did the department conduct a full public scoping procedure on the Jabiluka EIS; and (b) did this public scoping procedure involve the production of draft terms of reference for the EIS, followed by a period of public comment on those terms of reference, and then the production of final terms of reference in the light of the public comment; if not, why not.
(2) At what time did the final terms of reference for the Jabiluka EIS become available to: (a) the public; and (b) the proponent.
(3) At what time did those terms of reference become part of the actual process of preparation of the draft EIS by the proponent.

(4) Is the process of preparation of the draft EIS meant to be done in the light of the final terms of reference; if so, should the final terms of reference be available to the proponent early in the process of preparation of the draft EIS.
(5) In what manner, and to what extent, have the final terms of reference served as a basis for the draft EIS.
(6) How many comments have been received by the department on the draft terms of reference.
(7) What were the main points raised during the public comment process.

(8) (a) What suggestions made during the public comment process have actually been incorporated in the final terms of reference; and (b) to what extent are those suggestions reflected in the draft EIS itself.

(9) Can the Minister comment on the suggestion by some environmental groups that the administrative procedures indicate that the draft EIS should incorporate detailed information on the cost-benefit analysis of uranium projects, a full analysis of the `no action' alternative, the production of detailed feasibility studies and the preparation of a full cost/benefit and national interest assessment of the project.
(10) To what extent have these suggestions from environment groups been incorporated in the draft EIS.
(11) To what extent does the draft EIS reflect comments made by Aboriginal traditional owners on the draft terms of reference.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a)&(b) A public scoping procedure was conducted in order to develop the guidelines for the Jabiluka EIS. Draft guidelines were produced in consultation with the proponent and the Northern Territory Government and were released for public comment between 29 June and 29 July this year. The guidelines were finalised in the light of the public comment.

(2)(a)&(b) I endorsed the final guidelines on 13 September 1996. The proponent was informed of this on 24 September 1996. Members of the public and interest groups who made enquiries were informed of the finalisation of the guidelines and provided with a copy if requested. Printed copies of the final guidelines were sent on 16 October 1996 to:

PARA.TAB: people or organisations who made written comments on the draft guidelines;
people who attended meetings in the Northern Territory during the consultation period and provided a postal address; and
a number of other interest groups and organisations, including a number of Aboriginal associations in the Kakadu area.

ANSWER.PARA: (3) Preparation of the draft EIS began prior to approval of the final guidelines, on the basis of the requirements of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Administrative Procedures and draft guidelines provided in May 1996, which were subsequently amended and finalised in light of consultation and the public scoping process.
(4) It is normal practice for a proponent to begin preparation of a draft EIS on the basis of draft guidelines and to complete the draft EIS in light of the final guidelines.
(5) See (3) and (4) above.

(6) Sixteen written submissions were received on the draft guidelines during the public comment process. Approximately fifty to sixty members of the public attended consultation sessions held in Darwin and Jabiru, where comments were also noted and taken into account during the revision of the draft guidelines.
(7) The main points raised during the public comment process are as follows:

PARA.TAB: Scope. Submissions disagreed with the draft scoping limitation "assessment will not include more general issues concerning whether it is appropriate for uranium mining to occur in the Kakadu region". The limitation was seen as removing from public scrutiny one of the major issues in relation to this proposal, potentially restricting consideration of World Heritage issues and other aspects of the Kakadu region.
Scope. Submissions were opposed to the scoping restriction preventing consideration of the use of exported uranium in the nuclear fuel cycle.

Radiation. Submissions raised concerns relating to radiation, including: impact upon species, ecosystems, populations and traditional foods; baseline data on radiation in the existing environ ment including the Jabiluka deposit and capacity for soils to store and/or remobilise contaminants; assessment of radiation dose to the public from the existing situation (including Ranger); restriction upon traditional owner's land use due to mill tailings with long lived radioactive isotopes; and emissions of radiation as a result of mine ventilation.
ESD principles. Submissions proposed that the draft guidelines should require the proposal to fulfil ESD principles.
"No Project option". Submissions stressed the need for a comprehensive analysis of the "no project option".
Project Alternatives. In addition to major alternatives, submissions also requested inclusion and assessment of alternatives to details of the proposal (eg, alternative transportation methods etc).
Impacts upon Tourism. Submissions wanted this to be specifically referred to in the impacts section.
Cost Benefit Analysis. Submissions requested a specific analysis of the benefits and costs.

Specific Reference to the Kakadu Regional Social Impact Study (KRSIS). Submissions urged that the EIS be delayed until after the KRSIS had been completed. Some submissions also requested that the relationship between the EIS and the KRSIS be identified and explained in the guidelines.
Contingency Plans. Submissions raised the need for contingency plans. Some requested that the plans should actually be part of the EIS so that they could be assessed.
Risk Assessment. Submissions requested inclusion of other issues in the risk assessment section such as unplanned discharge, transport accidents, fire and explosion, blasting etc.
Anti-Uranium Stance. Submissions expressed opposition to all uranium exploration, mining, milling, processing and export.

Wishes of Traditional Owners. Submissions stated that the traditional owners have said they do not wish the Jabiluka project to proceed, and therefore this should prevent the project from proceeding. Submissions argued that given the wishes of the traditional owners, the EIS should not proceed.
Cumulative Impacts. Submissions requested that the EIS consider the cumulative impacts of all past uranium mining in the region as well as possible future mines (eg Koongarra).

ANSWER.PARA: (8)(a) The draft guidelines were amended in varying degrees to take account of most of the public comments. Some comments, such as those objecting in principle to uranium mining or criticising the environmental assessment process could not be reflected in the final guidelines. In some instances matters suggested for inclusion were already covered in the draft guidelines.
(b) My Department has not yet completed its examination of the draft EIS to establish whether the draft EIS meets the requirements of the guidelines.

(9) The guidelines require a comparative analysis of expected regional, Territory or national benefits and costs (including those that cannot be adequately described in monetary or physical terms eg. effects on cultural and aesthetic amenity). There is no specific requirement that the material presented should be analysed using cost-benefit analysis. Cost-benefit analysis can be a useful tool in appropriate circumstances, but it is only one technique among many and is not without its critics. There are inherent difficulties in applying cost-benefit analysis to assessments of environmental values and attributes. The guidelines require an analysis of not proceeding with the proposed development.
(10) See (7)-(9) above.

(11) No authors of written submissions or attendees at consultation sessions identified themselves as traditional owners of the proposal area. However a substantial submission was received from the Northern Land Council and was very useful in the revision of the guidelines.
